summary: Paul Merson has restarted his row with Andros Townsend, which began when Merson criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, stating that "if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody." Townsend subsequently scored an equalizer for England against Italy, leading Merson to admit his mistake, after which Townsend hit back on Twitter. Merson reignited the dispute by tweeting "#RubberDub #7minutes" after Townsend was brought on for only seven minutes in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old Japan international forward Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by club president Naoki Ogane. If Muto completes the move, he would join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. Ogane stated that Chelsea's interest in Muto is not connected to their Â£200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, which will become Chelsea's official shirt sponsors from the 2015-16 season in the biggest deal in the club's history. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree, has not yet decided whether to accept the offer, despite being honored by it.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers, suggesting these widely-prescribed drugs may contribute to the obesity epidemic, similar to their use in farm animals for weight gain. Published in Pediatrics, the research compared over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, revealing that children who received antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with repeated prescriptions before age two also increasing this likelihood, especially for boys. While not proving causation, researchers propose that antibiotics might kill gut bugs, freeing up more food for the body or increasing appetite. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized that early or repeated antibiotic exposure is associated with increased body mass in healthy children, underscoring the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy due to its potential role in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists during the popular Changing of the Guard ceremony, an incident caught on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell. The Queen's Guard lost his footing, slid sideways, knocked his bearskin, and dropped his rifle, quickly scrambling to his feet while appearing embarrassed. The slip is thought to have been caused by metal protectors on the soles of his boots, and the Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the matter.

The epic miniseries "Roots," which garnered over 100 million viewers in 1977, is being reimagined for new audiences by A&E networks, set to air in 2016. A&E, Lifetime, and History will simulcast the remake, which will tell the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version, described as "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. The remake aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation, many of whom may not know the story's importance, despite recent historical events like Barack Obama's presidency and the success of "12 Years a Slave," alongside widespread racial unrest.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in January 1978, when he was 27. Mr Lawler claims he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff on his first day, leaving him in tears, and he left the job the same day. He decided to contact palace officials again last year after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse, but his complaints were ignored for months before police were finally notified. A retired royal aide, now in his 80s, was reportedly interviewed but denied involvement, claiming he was working for the Queen in Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has told Mr Lawler it would work "exhaustively and co-operatively" with any police probe, and police are not commenting as investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video they made set to the theme from '90s television sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The clip, which features them rapping as they drive, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. In their parody, Melissa raps about living in Happy Valley, Oregon, and family asking about parenthood, while Jesse raps that they conceived faster than the two months they expected. Melissa then reveals she was late and a test showed a plus sign, indicating they are now three. At the end of the video, the Meeks smile and share a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple told KPTV it took five takes to film the clip, which was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby. Melissa told the Fox affiliate that the video's success was "completely unexpected," and Jesse told the Oregonian it was "way more than we ever expected." Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Melissa had earlier made a video capturing Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy, which he learned from a tag she placed on their dog. A Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, couple also made a pregnancy announcement video using 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' theme song last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, which featured over 150 items from the movie. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in several key scenes and was part of James Tumblin's private collection, who acquired it for $20 in the 1960s. Other notable sales included Leigh's straw hat for $52,500, Clark Gable's suit for $55,000, and a bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 book, is also notable for Hattie McDaniel becoming the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy is recovering after falling 10 to 12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday around 3pm, after his parents dangled him over the edge and he slipped from his mother's grasp. His parents rescued him from the pit before firefighters and paramedics arrived. The boy suffered minor bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs, which did not approach him or his parents. The Cleveland Metroparks Zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, previously used to enforce a 30mph limit, has been angled directly at a house's front door. This bright yellow gatso has not been working for two years, as all fixed speed and traffic cameras in the West Midlands were switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Around 300 such devices were decommissioned across the region, with enforcement now handled by mobile camera units, fixed cameras on motorways, and traffic officers. The re-pointing of the camera is a mystery, but Birmingham City Council is aware of the issue and an engineer will visit the site, with the camera potentially being removed completely. The council confirmed there are no plans to include this specific camera in a new pilot program using digital technology.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt confirmed his participation, stating he is "fit, healthy and ready to run" and aims to make his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability, anticipating "sprint magic" from the world's fastest man. The full Jamaican team list for the competition is expected to be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their dedication to Barcelona by attending the clubâs basketball El Clasico with Neymar's sister Rafaella, where Barca secured an 85-80 Euro League victory over Real Madrid, despite Real remaining top of their division. Neymar also captained Brazil to a 1-0 win against Chile at the Emirates Stadium, enduring several challenges. Prior to the international break, Luis Enrique's Barcelona had won their football El Clasico, establishing a four-point lead in La Liga, and Neymar and his team-mates are set to return to La Liga on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a rising wave of migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday, and 20 boats sending SOS calls on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants may be missing from a capsized ship carrying 550 people, based on survivor testimony, though the Italian coast guard cannot confirm this incident and has found no evidence. There has been an upsurge in migrant boats and rescues, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015, primarily from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by crews.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over other clubs, including Liverpool, after leaving Barcelona, though he doesn't know the exact reason for Sanchez's decision, acknowledging Liverpool's interest could have been leverage in the Luis Suarez transfer. Sanchez has made an instant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals this season, and Wenger praises his qualities and quick adaptation. Wenger has also played down speculation linking Arsenal with Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling and expressed admiration for Brendan Rodgers' management of Liverpool.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark). Wiggins, who is 35 on April 28 and has a strong track pedigree, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, calling the record a "holy grail for cyclists." The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, following reformed regulations by the UCI, with other recent attempts made by Jens Voigt, Matthias Brandle, and an upcoming one by Alex Dowsett. Tickets for Wiggins' attempt, expected to draw a 6,000-strong crowd, go on sale from April 19 at prices of Â£49, Â£39, and Â£29, and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins recently finished his Team Sky career and will ride in the Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for this challenge as part of his return to track cycling, targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams struggled to beat Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in the Fed Cup, calling it an "eye-opener" and realizing she was not ready for the claycourt season. The US team was ultimately beaten 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske losing their doubles match 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, leading to the US being relegated to World Group II. Tough weather conditions affected the play, and US captain Mary Joe Fernandez stated the team needs to work harder to return to the World Group.

River Plate is keen to sign former striker Radamel Falcao, who played for the Argentine side for eight years before leaving in 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Vice president Matias Patanian confirmed their interest, stating they "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open," though a deal is complicated. Falcao has struggled on loan at Manchester United, scoring four Premier League goals, and his future there or return to parent club Monaco is uncertain, despite recently equaling Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals after scoring three times in two games.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has become the official face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The 19-year-old singer is featured in campaign images showcasing various hairstyles against a blurred city background. The partnership, fused by the MILES agency, launched with an international TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson expressed excitement about working with Batiste, a product she regularly uses, while her manager, Mark Hargreaves, highlighted the natural synergy between the talented artist and the respected brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are in shock and have called a recently erected billboard featuring Officer Torres 'disrespectful'. Siler, 26, was shot after he 'armed himself with a weapon' following a vehicle and foot pursuit, while wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, features Torres and his dog, stating 'Thank you for your support, Kenosha'. Siler's family and friends interpret it as a thank you for killing Aaron and are asking for its removal, while the police association claims no offense was intended and it was simply to thank the community for its support. Torres is currently on leave pending the investigation into Siler's death, though a previous shooting by Torres of Terry Knight 10 days prior was determined to be justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan, with three militants also killed by Iranian forces in the southeastern town of Negur. The militants, who crossed from Pakistan, were from a group called Jaish al Adal, which claimed responsibility for the attack. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group from Pakistan's Balochistan province that targets Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence, having claimed previous attacks including one in October 2013 that killed 14 Iranian border guards. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to control these groups, while Pakistan condemned the recent attack as an "act of terrorism," is actively investigating, and has asked Iranian authorities to share any evidence, stating that if militants entered Pakistan after the attack, they would be apprehended.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani informed the Diet that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO), despite scrambling fighter jets for potential airspace violations. This statement was in response to a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who asked about extraterrestrial threats and research into alien visitors. Japanese politicians have previously discussed the implications of visitors from another planet, with former Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondering the legal ramifications of defending against an outer space invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution in 2007.

Passenger Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, smashed to the ground. He was standing on the rim because he was worried the seat might not be clean. The porcelain toilet tipped over and shattered, cutting him in several places, and he received dozens of stitches at a Hefei hospital. He initially confessed to friends about squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation, though authorities believed it was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting, not standing.
DID NOT RECIEIVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama, 37, has created a series of father-daughter portraits for his book, roughly translated as Daughter and Salary Man, which features fathers in sharp suits leaping into the air next to their casually dressed daughters, who look directly into the camera smiling. The images, set against various Japanese landmarks, aim to allow fathers to express their fun side as 'heroes jumping the sky', embodying excitement and hope, though some older fathers display pained expressions during their energetic jumps. This curious collection of photographs has garnered significant interest online.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director is a significant talking point in English cricket, with focus also shifting to the start of the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, controversially axed by Downton in 2014, displayed a range of emotions during the Surrey team photo at the KIA Oval, appearing both in deep thought and jovial. Downton's sacking has brought Pietersen, who last featured internationally during a disastrous Ashes tour in Australia, closer to a potential return to the England set-up. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test team, with Surrey scheduled to play Oxford MCCU on Sunday and Glamorgan on April 19.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani left them 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, a 41-year-old former Inter Milan and Parma right back capped 25 times by Brazil, was initially fired on Wednesday due to poor performance but reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. He had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach this season and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's loan move to Manchester United has been unsuccessful, with his former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believing Falcao regrets the transfer despite being unhappy in France. Falcao has struggled to score, netting only four goals all season, and has not reached his previous performance levels since a serious knee injury. Manchester United is unlikely to make his Â£46 million transfer permanent due to his struggles, and Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco where he would have played and participated in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday at approximately 12:30 pm. The offender, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, demanded cash from the owner's daughter at the Union St dairy in east Christchurch. He threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer and up to $1500 in cash. No weapons were used, and the robber remains at large, with police asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for a second time after a 15-year-old pupil accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. She was previously arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year. Granado was suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave, and was released on $50,000 bail after her second arrest.

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. New Zealander Tim Weston, on holiday, witnessed the event and identified the dog as belonging to the local bike shop's owner, noting the crocodile held the dog for hours. Weston explained that a crocodile sanctuary is located nearby, and the dog approached the water's edge. Crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta, inhabiting mangroves and a sanctuary, and are also spotted on golf courses, with American Crocodiles in Mexico reaching up to 6 meters and living closer to humans due to urbanization. Social media users reacted with horror to the video.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which left them battling to avoid relegation and just two points clear of the drop zone. Hull has six wins and six remaining games, including tough fixtures, with Bruce attributing their struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton's victory, with goals from James Ward-Prowse and Graziano Pelle, moved them to fifth in the table, though manager Ronald Koeman faced an internal issue when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty instead of the designated Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom after he allowed pupils to change their SATs exam answers and altered some himself after the test session had concluded. This conduct led to the Department for Education annulling all SATs exam results for the entire school for 2014. Guffick, who was forced to resign, admitted the allegations, though he claimed he only asked pupils to make answers more legible. A conduct panel found his actions dishonest, despite his regret and the pressure he may have felt, and he was subsequently banned from teaching for at least two years due to his deliberate actions and their serious impact on the school.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. They married last year in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together, having dated since 2012. Lindegaard, who moved to the Premier League in 2010, has struggled for playing time at Manchester United, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is now third-choice goalkeeper. Misse Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, regularly posts modelling photos on Instagram.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday, despite being expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000; only a Sotheby's employee made a $260,000 bid to start the process. Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008, owned the signage and wanted a new generation to enjoy the icon, which had beamed from atop the stadium since 1976 and was taken down in 2008. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, also auctioned by Sotheby's, sold for $112,500, significantly exceeding its $20,000 to $30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding their professional responsibilities after Sterling was exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide and both were pictured with shisha pipes, but neither player will be disciplined. Rodgers stressed that elite athletes must understand what they can and cannot do, and be seen doing, due to their welfare and responsibilities. Steven Gerrard is available for Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after a three-match suspension, though Rodgers has not confirmed if he will be recalled immediately. Rodgers' main priority is guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management, believing the team is ready to progress after previous close calls, and views past losses as part of the journey towards improvement.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after international duty, posting a picture relaxing with his dog, following Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia. He is now preparing for Arsenal's Premier League match against Liverpool, having missed the previous game against Newcastle due to illness, though claims of him being in a Berlin nightclub were dismissed by manager Arsene Wenger. Since returning from injury in January, Ozil has recorded four assists and three goals, and states he is now perfectly adjusted to English football despite its demanding schedule and lack of a winter break.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club is 'very happy' with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him, refuting speculation. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal until 2016, has impressed during his tenure and is only six games away from winning the title. Bartomeu noted that Barcelona is one of the few clubs capable of winning three trophies this season. Enrique's side recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, expected to be worth around Â£100,000-a-week and running until 2020. The 24-year-old vice-captain, who joined in June 2011, is the third player to extend his contract, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, who has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season, is being considered for the club captain role when Steven Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are anticipated to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis intends to remain at Chelsea until his contract concludes, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. Luis, who signed a three-year deal last July, has struggled to secure the left-back position. He recently played for Brazil in friendly wins against France and Chile. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is emphasizing focus and concentration for the remaining nine difficult Premier League games, with Luis stating the team is prepared for the challenge.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was sensationally overturned on appeal after an outcry. Hughes, a Wasps No 8, was initially suspended and shown a red card on March 27 for his knee colliding with North's head as North scored a try, with a disciplinary panel ruling him 'reckless' despite no intent. The dismissal has now been officially rescinded, with the appeal panel concluding that no act of foul play took place as the incident occurred accidentally, based on new evidence. George North was left unconscious, marking his third concussion in two months, and has been advised to take a month off. Hughes missed a Champions Cup quarter-final but is now free to return to action immediately, though he is unlikely to play until April 26.

Fiery sunsets observed in Washington, photographed by Tim Durkan, were caused by smoke from raging wildfires in Siberia. These fires originated in southeastern Siberia when farmers burning grass lost control on April 14 due to strong winds, leading to the destruction of dozens of villages. Lingering smoke was then carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red color of the sunsets is a result of smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange to penetrate unfiltered, a phenomenon particularly intense during sunrises and sunsets due to the greater amount of atmosphere light must travel through. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway and later found and returned to her on April 1. The car had been modified with new red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Rather than getting upset, Schoenig reacted positively, posting on Facebook to thank the car thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is having the car professionally cleaned due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana, and is also creating a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car.

Manchester City players face losing Â£500,000-a-man in bonuses, totaling around Â£12 million for the squad, if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. These incentivised contracts help the club meet financial fair play requirements. Following a defeat to Manchester United, City are in fourth place, with their European hopes in the balance, potentially only four points ahead of Liverpool if they win their next game. The top three Premier League finishers qualify automatically, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the season has disintegrated, impacting their ability to attract world-class players like Paul Pogba, who is also sought by Manchester United, now four points clear of City.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' held at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal from a free-kick just before the hour mark. The match featured a high number of English and Mancunian players, and was intended by United coach Paul McGuinness to simulate a senior match experience for his young players. This victory leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-hit City have now lost both of their Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off matches. The game showcased significant homegrown talent from both sides, suggesting potential for future first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart, who earned his 50th cap, praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon claimed his 147th cap. Hart, 10 years Buffon's junior, stated he is still learning from Buffon and finds him inspirational, expressing pride in his own milestone and a desire to continue playing for his club and country.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. This service will include a nine percent service charge and Postmates delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Chipotle had previously declined third-party delivery offers but has now approved Postmates, which uses independent contractors similar to Uber. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or launching delivery services. Additionally, presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have recently been spotted at Chipotle locations.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, are making an emotional plea to remove the death penalty as a sentencing option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 charges related to the 2013 attacks. In an opinion piece for The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son died and daughter Jane was severely injured, argue that pursuing the death penalty would lead to years of appeals, prolonging their family's anguish. They propose that the Justice Department take the death penalty off the table in exchange for Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison without release and waiving all appeal rights, believing this would allow them to "turn the page" and move towards a better future.

An enormous Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing Â£400 million and taking three years to customize. This custom-built aircraft, which normally carries up to 600 passengers, was designed for a single tycoon but can accommodate dozens of guests. It features multiple lounges, a master bedroom, eight full beds in an 'aeroloft', an onboard restaurant with an adjoining kitchen, a 'state room', a conference room, and an office/guest bedroom, all designed with a luxury hotel-like ambience.

SpaceX launched a two-stage Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. While the Dragon is en route to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and ISSpresso, and will later return over 3,000 pounds of science experiments and trash to Earth via a Pacific Ocean splashdown, SpaceX's attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing but tipping over. This difficult bid is part of founder Elon Musk's goal to reuse rockets like airplanes to reduce space access costs by as much as a factor of a hundred. This marks the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station, making them the first private space contractor to dock with the station, and Tuesday's launch was a second attempt after Monday's was scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on Thursday, April 23. She collaborated with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win this 'ultimate wedding', which includes a free reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who was involved in the chapel's design, stipulated that no impersonators would be allowed, emphasizing the first-class nature of the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside Memphis. Couples enter the contest by submitting a video or photos and an explanation.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side could catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite City being four points ahead. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in Liverpool's 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equalling a record for appearances in top European leagues. Manchester City recently lost 4-2 to Manchester United. In the match against Newcastle, Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen scored his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes remaining, though Allen admitted he thought Newcastle had a strong shout for a penalty.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, a key match for Champions League places. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made crucial saves in the second half to secure the win. This result moved second-place Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, keeping them in fifth. Security was tight for the match, with residents from the Campania region barred from buying tickets and 1,000 police officers present, but no problems were reported. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne returned from injury late in the game.

Doncaster Rovers had an uninspired season in League One, firmly entrenched in mid-table mediocrity. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium resulted in a goalless 0-0 draw, which tested the patience of fans and presented a challenge for the media team. Consequently, the club's YouTube channel featured a very short highlight video, only 27 seconds long with 14 seconds of match action, showing just the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, which he interacts with by stroking and massaging it in its tank. The fish, initially hesitant, returns to his hand, appearing to enjoy the sensation, staying still, swimming up his arm, circling his fingers, and burying its face in his hand. It shows sadness when he removes his hand. Giroux, who uploads videos of his fish to YouTube, began this interaction after removing two other fish that were bullying his pet. He hand-fed it frozen bloodworms, making it more sociable, and now the fish enjoys being stroked, becoming frustrated if not played with daily for at least 15 minutes. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes has returned to the England team after a year of ups and downs, including breaking his wrist punching a locker, which serves as a reminder to channel his aggression. Known as a fiery character, he has clashed with opponents like Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson, but England coach Peter Moores has man-managed him to ensure his aggression is controlled and productive, leading to runs and wickets. Despite a slight back niggle, Stokes is valued for his character in a game perceived as producing 'robots', and England wants to nurture his natural exuberance while ensuring his feistiness remains natural and controlled. The team aims to play Stokes and Chris Jordan as much as possible to help them grow into the international game, as two spinners will rarely be needed this summer.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out, with both teams tied on 11 points in Group B, Belgium leading on goal difference. This places Wales in their best position to qualify for a major tournament since 1958, especially after a recent 3-0 victory over Israel boosted expectations for them to reach the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales confirmed the overwhelming demand for tickets, and the match will be held at the Cardiff City Stadium, not the Millennium Stadium, due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days and the squad's preference for the more intimate venue.

England coach John Peacock has named the squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the defending champions, who qualified with a 100 per cent record, are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their campaign begins against Italy on May 7 in Burgas, followed by matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (first call-up) from Arsenal, and recalled Liverpool players Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from Anderlecht's youth system and has also attracted attention from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 because his family wanted him to continue his studies. City has held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to agree on a compensation package, as Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the young star for future development.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort and Mexican national, was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March, having suffered injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed for further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. She worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, and had expressed her love for London online before her death.

Dawn, a woman who suffered seven miscarriages, had Â£207 stolen, which was intended for a Â£500 gravestone for her baby, Daniel James. She accused her housemate and family friend, Jamie, of taking the money on The Jeremy Kyle show. A lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, and he had also confessed via Facebook message, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed her distress and feeling of betrayal over the incident.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women and children, along with some ill or elderly, on Wednesday, with Arab tribal leaders reportedly helping to coordinate the release, though the motivation remained unclear. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. This follows ISIS's actions last summer when they overtook Yazidi towns in northern Iraq, leading to the killing, capturing, and displacement of this minority group of Kurdish descent, whose pre-Islamic religion draws from Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism. ISIS's conquest of Sinjar, in particular, caused a major humanitarian crisis, with reports of slaughter, rape, and enslavement, prompting an international coalition to respond with aid and airstrikes targeting ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham and England player, has had a remarkable season, leading to nominations for both PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. He is featured in a new animation produced by Copa90, which uses still photographs to depict some of his best goals and celebrations, including a long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his goal on England debut. Titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', the video was released ahead of Sunday's awards ceremony where Kane is nominated alongside players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead Liverpool, despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four, stating that a manager's future shouldn't be determined by one game and that new players haven't yet bedded in. Rodgers' future has been questioned after a third straight season without a trophy, with Liverpool currently seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City and set to miss Champions League qualification. Carragher expects Rodgers, the players, and staff to aim for a trophy and a top-four finish next season, emphasizing the importance of making the right signings. Separately, Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, where his 23 Foundation provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas, driven by his desire to help youngsters from underprivileged backgrounds.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf toy gun, which fires sponge darts, confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security officers deemed it a security risk when it was picked up on X-ray machines in his hand luggage. James was also frisked by security. His father, Phil Hayward, criticized the 'over-zealous' and 'ludicrous' security checks. The family was flying to Lanzarote for 10 days over Easter, and James was bought a replacement toy gun after their return. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to post the toy back, defending their decision by stating that government regulations and Department of Transport rules prohibit items resembling prohibited items, including 'replica or model guns'.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife, detailing specific requirements for his 'dream girl' including loving pets, being a non-drinker/smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, good with hands, a good cook, great in bed, and enjoying the outdoors while also being a 'princess'. He offered benefits such as accommodation, a potential company car, phone, laptop, and free gym membership to the 'successful candidate'. Rich described himself as having an athletic build, white, heavily tattooed, brown hair and eyes, a non-drinker/smoker/drug user, 175cm tall, 'WELL Endowed', owning properties, making great money, successful, loving cars and bikes, and being very independent and generous with his woman. He promised 'all reasonable offers will be considered' but stated former partners need not apply.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is seeking to implement radical changes, including increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and redefining 'home-grown' to mean training in England for three years before the age of 18. While facing opposition from the Premier League, Dyke has the backing of five former England managersâGraham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClarenâwho warn that blocking these proposals risks England falling further behind leading football nations and hindering their chances of winning the World Cup. They highlight that only 36.8 per cent of Premier League starters are eligible for England selection and that the pool of English talent at the top level is shrinking, with promising young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane lacking opportunity.

Demelza Poldark is now the proud mother to a new baby daughter, with Ross Poldark gazing lovingly at her, confirming his heart is off the market despite women longing to settle down with him. However, the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is unconvincing, as she goes from barely showing to eight months pregnant, then gives birth within minutes in tomorrow's episode, without any nod to the passing of time. Fans noticed this fast progression, comparing it to a previous pregnancy in the show where Elizabeth went to full term between episodes.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to maintain focus on their own games and ignore relegation rivals, despite being three points from safety at the bottom of the Barclays Premier League. Following back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom with an injury-time winner from Jamie Vardy, Pearson emphasizes that Leicester's future is in their own hands and warns against becoming overly optimistic. He wants the team to concentrate on their own run-in to give themselves a realistic chance of survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific to Baja, Mexico. This journey, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Lead author Bruce Mate suggests Varvara's visit to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales indicates she may originate from Mexico, and her extensive travel ability raises the possibility that some whales previously thought to be endangered western gray whales are actually eastern grays, potentially lowering the estimated population of western gray whales and prompting a re-examination of genetic differentiation between the species.

On the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, near Rausu on the Shiretoko Peninsula, approximately 1,000 to 1,640 feet of seabed was forced to the surface overnight, creating a new stretch of coastline that rose 30 to 50 feet high and measured 100 feet wide. Geologists attribute this emergence to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater area into the air. Local residents were surprised, reporting no tremors or sounds, and authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further, clarifying it is not related to earthquakes, including the recent one in Kathmandu. Marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims he is leaving Paris Saint-Germain this summer, reiterating his love for the club, city, and teammates, and expressing a desire to sign a new contract. This follows a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea. Van der Wiel insists he is happy and ready to play when called upon, though Paris Saint-Germain's links to Barcelona star Dani Alves could impact his future with the club.

Carlos Tevez reportedly wishes to leave Juventus this summer to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, despite his contract with Juventus not expiring until the end of next season. Boca Juniors have confirmed they are close to a deal, but their president, Daniel Angelici, stressed that Tevez must first terminate his contract with the Italian club. Juventus, though reluctant to lose their top scorer who has netted 17 times this season, have accepted his desire to leave and are identifying replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that his club choice would not impact his Argentina future, emphasizing that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are great teams.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena in a Champions League match, securing their place in the semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Despite Porto holding a two-goal lead from their 3-1 victory in Portugal, Bayern swept them aside. During the exciting match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola ripped the left trouser leg of his grey garments, exposing his underwear, and joked about needing new trousers for the next match, also ditching his suit blazer in the latter stages.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, Brisbane's west, on Wednesday afternoon, involving ten people, including four children. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment, while a man suffered hand lacerations and two females escaped injury. Emergency crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free one person trapped in a vehicle, and the highway was closed for a few hours with diversions in place.

Second-placed Arsenal are set to host table toppers Chelsea in a crucial Premier League match on Sunday. Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, which he showcased on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch, and is expected to start the upcoming game. Arsenal currently trails Chelsea by 10 points with six league games remaining. Jack Wilshere has returned from a five-month injury layoff, having been on the bench for Arsenal's FA Cup semi-final win. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere is the future of Arsenal if he can maintain fitness, but expresses concern over his injury record, likening it to Abou Diaby's.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford on Sunday, despite having sent off two Manchester United players in the Premier League this season (Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw) and City captain Vincent Kompany during an international match. Manchester United are currently one point above Manchester City, making the derby crucial for deciding who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea. United enter the match with confidence, having won their last five consecutive league games, while City have struggled. Clattenburg will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, and Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing embattled MP Billy Gordon was 'a little black puppet on a string' after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and admitted to a criminal past, leading him to quit the Queensland Labor Party but remain an independent. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent and has experienced racist attitudes, stated he sympathized with Gordon and deliberately used the term 'black puppet' due to his personal experiences and to highlight perceived racial overtones, questioning why Gordon was assumed to resign unlike federal cases. Katter's statement sparked criticism on social media, with users questioning his terminology, though he defended it by saying he used the term 'because I'm dark and I come from Cloncurry' and could identify with the attitudes. He also used federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independents becoming puppets for the government, vowing Mr Gordon would not make that mistake.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates enthusiastic dancing videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Having faced bullying and staring, she aims to counteract the perception that her disability prevents her from doing things or makes her different, emphasizing that she is much like everyone else, driving, attending college, and dancing despite doctors' initial warnings that she might never walk. Dayna hopes her videos entertain, inspire people to think before judging, and encourage others to look past her disability, and she has also begun motivational speaking at local schools to turn negativity into something positive.

MLS side Orlando City has expressed interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid and has had a difficult season. Orlando City, coached by Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, sees Hernandez as a commercial draw and a popular arrival due to their large Latin-American fanbase. Manchester United is willing to sell Hernandez for approximately Â£8 million, with eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan also keen on the player who has one year left on his contract. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who rejected their initial offer and has attracted interest from clubs like Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord, with Pereira having been on the bench against Aston Villa.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and set it on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15 am on Saturday, after the driver got into an argument with the suspects. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, pulling out a gun, before lighting the vehicle ablaze with two passengers inside. No one was injured, but the car was completely ruined. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, with suspects remaining at large and surveillance video being used in the investigation.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic detailed these charges, and Manuel admitted his misdeeds, agreeing not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement also requires him to prove the circumstances, including bartering sex for services, no longer exist before he can resume practicing. Manuel also recommended that patients stop taking prescribed medication. Despite these accusations, he received outstanding patient satisfaction evaluations on HealthGrades.com, with a perfect five out of five stars from three patient survey responses. His practice's address was listed on a residential street in Lamoni.

The United States is complaining to Moscow after a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland earlier this week. The U.S. crew considered the Russian pilot's aggressive maneuvers and close proximity dangerous, while Russia claimed the U.S. plane's transponder was off and the jet was identifying it, a claim the U.S. denied. This incident follows a similar "dangerous close pass" a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk, and Russian and U.S. aircraft frequently encounter each other in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car's window in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot overnight on March 27, just days before President Obama visited Utah. The rifle, secured properly in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was believed to have been taken by a thief who broke the rear passenger-side window, tied a rope to the case, and used another vehicle's momentum to rip it free, pulling the window frame from the door. Also stolen were the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools, though the bags and some clothing were later found at a nearby hotel; the sniper rifle remains unrecovered. The theft occurred at the Marriott Springhill Suites, which lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, with the Secret Service notified prior to the President's visit.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Canberra by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. A jury heard that Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and concluded that his brain was compromised by dementia and alcohol, leading to a confused state where he would not have understood his actions or their consequences, a view supported by his fluctuating mood during triple 0 calls and a trail of faeces at the scene. Professor Mullen denied the prosecutor's suggestion that Costa feigned memory loss, stating it was likely Costa suffered from a demented illness for a significant period leading up to the event. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as proving an unstable mindset at the time of the attack could result in a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended a penalty incident after Ross Barkley missed a 10th-minute spot-kick in their 1-0 win against Burnley, awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon. Barkley took the penalty despite the presence of Leighton Baines, who has a strong penalty record, recalling a similar incident against West Brom where Kevin Mirallas also missed after taking a penalty from Baines. Martinez stated Barkley was within his rights to take it, emphasizing players taking control and that Baines was happy to concede the responsibility. Barkley's effort was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal of the game after 29 minutes, meaning the miss did not prove costly.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship at 11:30 a.m. Thursday, with the cruise line, Holland America Line, stating it appears to be a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating. The ship, which left Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico, where cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has made a winning start as coach of Curacao, leading the Caribbean island team to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced by winning 4-3 on aggregate against Montserrat, following a 2-2 draw in the second-leg match where former Holland Under 21 international Charlton Vicento scored in the 87th minute. Kluivert's team will now face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup losing semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and in 2014 as assistant to coach Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, a player with an illustrious career and numerous major European trophies, considers keeping Leicester City in the Premier League to be among his best achievements, equating it to winning a trophy. Leicester is currently seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with eight games remaining, but Cambiasso remains convinced they can avoid relegation. He won 15 trophies during his ten years at Inter Milan, including the Champions League and FIFA Club World Cup, and also achieved success with River Plate and Real Madrid. Cambiasso, who signed a one-year deal with Leicester in the summer, has established himself as a key player and is happy in the East Midlands, potentially staying beyond his current contract.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two children under five, faces a ban from seeing her children by her 52-year-old mother, Debbie, who has cared for them since they were four months old. Debbie is threatening the ban due to Gemma's refusal to stop drinking and partying, her use of the legal high MKat, and suspicions of stealing, including an alleged theft of an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle. Gemma, who is unemployed, denies stealing the iPad but admits to past thefts from her mother. Debbie states Gemma went "off the rails" from age 13 and gave up on motherhood, leading Debbie to raise the children, who now call her "mum." Debbie is preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she cannot trust her not to steal their possessions.

Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead against Manchester United, but the Sky Sports punditry team believed a foul occurred in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, sending him to the ground, after which Cesc Fabregas collected the loose ball, leading to Hazard's goal. Pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that Terry's tackle on Falcao, described by Souness as a "decent forearm smash" and an elbow to the back of Falcao's head, should have resulted in play being stopped, with Henry expressing sympathy for Falcao and Redknapp stating it was still a foul despite Falcao possibly being able to stay on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas, after a rear tire blew out. Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were all safely evacuated before the bus burst into flames. Witness Michael Barnett captured video of the incident. Scott posted on Instagram about their safety, noting that her Bible was the only item saved from the bus's back lounge. The other band members were not on the bus, and Lady Antebellum is still set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sun beams into energy for heating homes. Satellites covered in mirrors will harvest sunlight, convert it into laser light using semi-conductors, and then beam the energy back to Earth to power homes, boost solar panels, and restore power to disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and future trials are planned for Portugal. Unlike science fiction depictions, these lasers are not powerful enough to be weapons or blind a pigeon, though Dr Quarterman acknowledges potential concerns about who controls the satellites.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile with a fanatical obsession with young girls, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, since 6:15 pm on Tuesday. He was detained under a hospital order following his conviction last August for sexually touching a three-year-old girl and for ten unrelated offences of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. Munden, described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, with dark hair, may have shaved his beard and suffers from learning difficulties and autism, having difficulty controlling his sexual interest in small children. Officers have launched a manhunt and are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

Donald Sterling's racist remarks led to him losing his NBA team, and subsequently, his former female companion, V. Stiviano, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts. This ruling came after Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, sued Stiviano, accusing her of targeting wealthy older men and claiming Donald used their money to buy Stiviano luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that the gifts were legitimate and she never took advantage of Sterling, but Shelly Sterling's lawyer celebrated the decision as a victory for the family and a precedent for injured spouses. Sterling's downfall was triggered by an audio recording where he chastised Stiviano for posting pictures with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson, resulting in NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banning him from the league, fining him $2.5 million, and terminating his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged his former club to purchase four top playersâa goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and strikerâto have any chance of winning the Barclays Premier League title. Speaking after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry also stated that Arsenal would struggle to win the league if Olivier Giroud remains the first-choice striker, despite Giroud scoring 14 league goals this season. He cited Chelsea's success after acquiring players like Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of the competitive additions Arsenal needs. Arsenal are currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City with a game in hand.

Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One young woman, a victim, testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe and lasting impact of his abuse on her life, stating she is scared for future relationships, feels her right to share her body was stolen, and has suffered from depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide. She kept the abuse secret for years, not knowing it was wrong as a child, but spoke out after learning he had been caught, and now worries about him being released and how the abuse will forever affect her relationships with men. Van Ryn is currently in custody, and the hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder and Germany Under-21 international, is preparing to return to play after more than a year out due to a serious knee injury that has kept him from featuring since March 2014. Gnabry, who impressed for the Gunners last season before his injury, recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading and reports feeling "better and better" and "over his injury worries."

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old graduate accountant, died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, in December. He had been out drinking with friends and ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare because they didn't have enough money. In the dark, he leapt over a fence and plunged down the cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, gave chase but stopped when he couldn't see. Mr Phillips' body was discovered the next day by a dog walker, and a coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating he likely became disorientated and was unaware of the danger.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, despite the passport agency making a Â£42 million profit and its managers receiving up to Â£3,500 in bonuses. Ministers refused a blanket refund for families who paid extra or missed trips, even though problems arose from HM Passport Office struggling with 3.6 million applications, leaving over half a million stuck. While urgent cases were offered free upgrades, thousands had already paid Â£30. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April last year and January this year, totaling Â£203,066, with an average payout of Â£92.68. The Passport Office could not provide rejection figures due to a 'system failure', and Ministers rejected calls for full compensation to avoid setting a precedent.

A three-bedroom, semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, largely unchanged since the 1930s, is up for sale with a guide price of Â£200,000 to Â£250,000. This "collector's paradise" retains numerous original features including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black original bathroom, a kitchen with 1930s cupboards, and a wood-panelled hallway, along with vintage food tins. Despite being double-glazed, potential renovation costs are a concern for developers, though it is seen as a perfect family home for antique enthusiasts. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith, becoming the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith sustained a concussion. He remained the team's starting quarterback for the rest of that season, leading the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there, and later moved to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast, through its NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London, and around Colchester, Essex, attending the Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon. They formed Blur, whose debut album Leisure was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Drawing influences from alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop music, the band released their self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo studio album, Everyday Robots, co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and sampling rants by Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and as such, many important national institutions are based there.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their 1992 debut extended play, Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American BAFTA-nominated screenwriter.

The 2007 film "Shooter" features Mark Wahlberg as Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. The "Shooter" TV series stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is coaxed back into action after discovering a plot to kill the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that ran for eight seasons on the Fox network, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, which were carried out by members of his group at his instruction. He also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television with Little House on the Prairie in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn, and made his film debut in Taps (1981). After diverse roles in the 1980s, including Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), Penn gained critical attention for films like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). He became a prominent leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received further Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and won two Academy Awards for Best Actor for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George `` Don '' Bradman, also known as `` The Don '', was an Australian cricketer born on 27 August 1908 and died on 25 February 2001, widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. After his retirement, Bradman maintained a prominent role in the game for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held significant leadership positions in the music industry, including serving as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment, the president and CEO of Arista Records, and the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his career in 1990 with Greta and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he is playing in the band Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, comprising 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS announced its cancellation on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 â September 13, 2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she first gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas, delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas, noted for her outspoken feminism and one-liners, and was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards (October 1, 1935 â April 1, 1982) was a separate individual, an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP titled A Reminder in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, born Jeanette Helen Morrison, was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author (July 6, 1927 â October 3, 2004) who wrote four books, including two novels, between 1984 and 2002.

SimÃ³n JosÃ© Antonio de la SantÃ­sima Trinidad BolÃ­var y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on 24 July 1783 and died on 17 December 1830. He played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where a number of aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith, becoming the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994 that season, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual form of marketing communication that employs an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It is differentiated from personal selling because its message is nonpersonal, not directed to a particular individual. Advertising is communicated through various mass media, including old media such as newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, or direct mail, and new media such as search results, blogs, websites, or text messages.
Private Lives refers to both a 1930 three-act comedy of manners play by NoÃ«l Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 â 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle, an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice (384-322 BC), joined Plato's Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen and remained there until he was thirty-seven (c. 347 BC). After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, tutored Alexander the Great starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is currently the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, joining them as the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft after high school and college championships. He secured a championship and an NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award in his rookie season, adding four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s. After a four-year retirement due to player protests, he returned in 1996 for 32 games before retiring for the third and final time. Johnson also has numerous business interests, was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years, and was recognized by Ebony magazine in 2009 as one of America's most influential black businessmen.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. The band has released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). They gained popularity in 1997 through their eponymous television series and by supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I, born 19 June 1566 and died 27 March 1625, reigned as King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death, ruling these individual sovereign states in personal union. He strongly advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland, achieving most of his goals in Scotland but encountering significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and frequent conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality television series, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, most famous for narrating the UK's Big Brother since 2000. He previously did continuity announcements for Channel 4 until July 2011, then continued narrating Big Brother on Channel 5, and his voice-over work and Geordie accent have made him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state of Germany, bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is Germany's tenth largest state by area (18,413 km2) and sixth most populous with 4 million people, and its history spans over a millennium. Saxony is also a quality wine region within the state, one of Europe's northernmost, and one of only two of Germany's 13 wine regions located in former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park located in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati in the United States, while "In the End" is a song by American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing the song "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles.
