Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Raveena Tandon replaced Divya Bharti as the female lead after Bharti's death, despite Bharti having completed shooting for many scenes. The film is also remembered for its chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, recognized for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and for his directorial debut with the 2005 film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond spy film and the seventh and final film to feature Roger Moore as the MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, encompassing most of western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya, and before that West Irian or Irian Barat, and formerly comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggested his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez debuted in the music industry in 1999 with her album On the 6, featuring the single "If You Had My Love". In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album, J.Lo, and film, The Wedding Planner, simultaneously. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album This Is Me... Then, and overshadowed the film Gigli. She later married Marc Anthony and found success with Shall We Dance?, giving birth to twins in 2008. Lopez returned to prominence in 2011 as an American Idol judge and with her commercially successful single "On the Floor".

A working animal is typically a domesticated animal kept by humans and trained for specific tasks. These tasks can include being close family members like guide or assistance dogs, providing tractive force such as draft horses or logging elephants, or assisting with milking and herding, which requires human training for cooperation. While wild animals can sometimes be tamed and trained for work, it is often for novelty or entertainment, as they generally lack the trustworthiness and mild temper characteristic of true domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Billboard magazine publishes two record charts: Top Latin Albums, which is the most important music chart for Spanish language, full-length albums in the American music market, and Regional Mexican Albums, a genre-specific chart published weekly in the United States.

Vedam, which translates to "Chant" in English, is a 2010 Telugu language Indian drama film. It was written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi and features a cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character from Don Quixote, a novel written by Spanish author Don Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra in 1605. He serves as Don Quixote's squire and offers comments, known as "sanchismos," which blend broad humour, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film directed by Ron Underwood, starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler, attended by Ibsen, took place on January 31, 1891, at the Residenztheater in Munich.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born on 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., known as Juve, is a professional Italian association football club based in Turin, Piedmont. Founded in 1897 by young Torinese students, including Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico, it is the second oldest active club of its kind in Italy after Genoa's football section (1893). The club has traditionally worn a black and white striped home kit since 1903 and currently plays its home matches at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in various films and television series during the late 1990s and early 2000s, including the films Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), and the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress, recognized as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." She began acting in erotic videos in 1993, following her earlier work as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a National Basketball Association (NBA) team, competing as a member club of the league's Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, originally by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually via pay-per-view television. Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP), which traditionally held major professional wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, mostly at Greensboro Coliseum, from the 1960s to the 1980s, produced several Starrcade events under the NWA banner, including the third annual Starrcade (1985) and the fifth annual Starrcade (1987). Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual pay-per-view event.

Jack Ryan Falahee, born February 20, 1989, is an American actor known for his role as Connor Walsh on the ABC legal drama How to Get Away with Murder and as Benjamin Stringfellow on the PBS historical drama Mercy Street.

"Don't Say No" is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun, whose real name is Seo Ju-hyun, born June 28, 1991. Seohyun is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted in August 2007 as a member of the girl group Girls' Generation and its subgroup TTS, which became one of South Korea's best-selling and most popular girl groups worldwide. She has also established herself as an actress through stage musicals like "Moon Embracing the Sun," "Gone with the Wind," and "Mamma Mia." Seohyun debuted as a solo artist with "Don't Say No" on January 17, 2017, making her the third Girls' Generation member to do so.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak and introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Steve Jobs oversaw the development of its case and Rod Holt developed the power supply. The series was trademarked as "Apple ][" and later "Apple //". Steve Wozniak, nicknamed "Woz," is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc. and was born on August 11, 1950.

A&E, formerly Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel and the flagship property of A&E Networks. A&E Networks is a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and the Disney-ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company, with both entities maintaining a 50% ownership interest.

L.A. Reid has held significant leadership positions in the music industry, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. He also founded and was CEO of Hitco Music Publishing, and co-founded LaFace Records.

Veeram (Valour) refers to two different Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

Home for the Holidays is a 1972 American made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972. There is also a 1995 film titled Home for the Holidays, which stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.

Sikkim is a northeastern state of India.
Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius "Ron" Weasley is a fictional character featured in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder and produced by his brother Jack Binder. Distributed by Columbia Pictures, the film was released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3, 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

Sheryl Lee appeared in CafÃ© Society in 2016 and completed the Showtime revival of Twin Peaks (2017), reprising her role as Laura Palmer. In 2016, Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Wicked on Broadway.
Matteo Renzi, born on 11 January 1975, is an Italian politician who held the position of Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The film "The Road to El Dorado" stars Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

"Same Old Love" is a song by American singer Selena Gomez from her second studio album, Revival, released in 2015. Revival debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, and its first three singles, "Good for You," "Same Old Love," and "Hands to Myself," all topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that emerged primarily in the United Kingdom and the United States during the late 1960s and early 1970s, with bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon continuing in a similar style as part of the new wave of British heavy metal from the late 1970s onwards.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in several romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman, a men's clothing store chain, is part of the Arcadia Group, which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins. Topman operates high-street stores throughout the United Kingdom, with a presence on nearly every UK High Street, and has main street outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.

At the dawn of the Industrial Revolution, Wales transformed from an agricultural society into an industrial nation due to the development of mining and metallurgical industries, with the exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield causing a rapid expansion of its population.
Tool has achieved three Grammy Awards, conducted worldwide tours, and produced albums that topped charts in multiple countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California, and is ranked as the second most popular site globally by Alexa Internet, a web traffic analysis company.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born on 22 November 1968, is a Danish actress who works in theatre, television, and film.

Conrad Dunn began his screen career in 1981 with the role of Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the film Stripes, which also marked a significant first film role for him and several other actors including John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.

Asylum Records is an American record label established in 1971 by founders David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, primarily Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. Other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups, such as the Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, were similarly targeted for extermination by the Ottoman government in the Assyrian genocide and the Greek genocide, with their treatment considered by some historians to be part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19, 1946, is an American politician who served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration as president was held on January 20, 1993, on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, born 20 October 1956, is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director, recognized for films such as Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours, and Steve Jobs. The Beach is a 2000 adventure drama film directed by Danny Boyle, adapted by John Hodge from Alex Garland's 1996 novel.

Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar (22 January 1917 â 11 June 2006) was an officer in the British Army.

The Others (2001 film) won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director, making it the first English-language film to receive the Best Film Award at the Goyas without any Spanish spoken. The film was also nominated for six Saturn Awards, including Best Director and Best Writing for AmenÃ¡bar and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann, ultimately winning three: Best Horror Film, Best Actress for Kidman, and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan.
Ralph Fults (January 23, 1911 â March 16, 1993) was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist who was associated with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, religious name Tenzin Gyatso, born Lhamo Thondup on 6 July 1935, is the current Dalai Lama. He was born in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet, and was selected as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937, then formally recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama in 1939. During the 1959 Tibetan uprising, he fled to India, where he currently lives as a refugee.

Miracle at St. Anna is a film primarily set in German-occupied Italy during World War II, following four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who find refuge in a small Tuscan village and bond with its residents. The story is told as a flashback, with a survivor reflecting on his experiences in a frame story set in 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born November 27, 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

Home for the Holidays (1995) is a film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, where she spent much of her early life before moving to Texas, and later to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma, and raised in Anaheim, California, where he developed a childhood fascination with the ocean and an interest in art.

Many religious orders, such as Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, some Sufi dervishes, and Jainism and Buddhism monastic orders, follow a mendicant way of life. A monk, derived from the Greek "monachos" meaning "single, solitary," is an individual who practices religious asceticism through monastic living, either alone or in a group. A monk may choose to dedicate their life to serving all other living beings or to live as an ascetic apart from mainstream society, focusing on prayer and contemplation.
The Mod Squad is an American crime drama series that aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American science fantasy western action horror film, directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona is a state in the southwestern United States, ranking as the sixth largest and 14th most populous of the 50 states. It became the 48th state and the last of the contiguous states admitted to the Union on February 14, 1912. Approximately one-quarter of Arizona is comprised of Indian reservations, which are home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in both the state and the United States with over 300,000 citizens. The state is known for its high population of Native Americans.
Smriti Mandhana, born on 18 July 1996, is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women's cricket team.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson, born on 15 April 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist. She was born in Paris, raised in Oxfordshire, attended the Dragon School, and trained as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s, following her attainment of a bachelor of arts degree from Yale University and a master of fine arts degree from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is NASA's highest award, presented by the President of the United States in Congress's name based on recommendations from the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. To receive it, an astronaut must perform feats of extraordinary accomplishment during space flight under NASA's authority. Frank Frederick Borman, II, born March 14, 1928, a retired USAF Colonel, is also mentioned.
The Saw franchise films collectively grossed over $873 million at the box office worldwide.
Down with Love is a romantic comedy film released in 2003.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for his roles as Joe Wicks in BBC's EastEnders and as DS Sam Casey in ITV's Law & Order: UK.
Colombiana is a 2011 French action film that was co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was a member of the main cast in the Netflix original series Marco Polo, which was cancelled on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Boyhood is a film shot from 2002 to 2013, which portrays the childhood and adolescence of Mason Evans, Jr. (Coltrane) from ages six to eighteen, growing up in Texas with his divorced parents (Arquette and Hawke).
Hush (2016 film) was produced by Trevor Macy, through Intrepid Pictures, and Jason Blum, through his Blumhouse Productions banner.

The Penibaetic System, also known as Sistema PenibeÌtico or Cordillera PenibeÌtica, is the southernmost of the three mountain range systems within the Baetic System, located in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos (apparel) provides a full line of men's suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories. Topman, a part of the Arcadia Group, operates a chain of high-street men's clothing stores across the United Kingdom and has main street outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.
"Roar" is a song by American singer Katy Perry, released as the lead single from her fourth studio album, Prism (2013), on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation, also known as Saturn LLC, is a registered trademark established on January 7, 1985, as a subsidiary of General Motors.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, primarily Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. These mass killings began under Ottoman rule in 1915, and Turkey, as the successor state, denies the term "genocide" as an accurate description.

Muslims believe the Quran was verbally revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel (Jibril) over approximately 23 years, starting on 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40, and concluding in 632, the year of his death.

The human brain, along with the spinal cord, constitutes the central nervous system and is composed of the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum. The cerebrum is the largest part of the human brain, and beneath its cerebral cortex are several important structures including the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures (amygdala and hippocampus), claustrum, various nuclei of the basal ganglia, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a British comedy drama film from 2017, set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network that offers programming including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to content, hunting and fishing, children's shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George `` Don '' Bradman (27 August 1908 -- 25 February 2001), known as `` The Don '', was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. He was a national icon whose opinion was highly sought even in his declining years, with Prime Minister John Howard calling him the `` greatest living Australian '' in 2001, more than 50 years after his retirement as a Test player.

Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher (1925â2013), was a British stateswoman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. She was the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold that office. In 1975, Thatcher defeated Heath to become Leader of the Opposition and the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom.

Randy Mario Poffo, known by his ring name "Macho Man" Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator born on November 15, 1952, and died on May 20, 2011. He was best known for his time in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and World Championship Wrestling (WCW).
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor whose career has spanned over five decades.

EA Black Box, formerly Black Box Games, was a video game developer based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada. It was founded in 1998 by former employees of Radical Entertainment and was later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae was an ancient Italian mineral springs and coastal resort on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples. Herculaneum, an ancient Roman town in the commune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy, was destroyed by volcanic pyroclastic flows in 79 AD, located in the shadow of Mount Vesuvius. Naples is near culturally and historically significant sites like the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum. Famous ruins are found worldwide, including ancient sites in China, the Indus valley, Judea, Zimbabwe, ancient Greek, Egyptian, and Roman sites in the Mediterranean basin, and Incan and Mayan sites in the Americas.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama starring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin, set in 1980 West Texas, following a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran. Tommy Lee Jones's other notable roles include Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in No Country for Old Men, Agent K in the Men in Black film series, Woodrow F. Call in Lonesome Dove, and Pete Perkins in The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, which he also directed.
Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, located in the San Francisco Bay Area of the United States, and its name means "tall tree."

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born Albert Lawrence Einstein on July 22, 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian. Finding Dory was directed by Andrew Stanton with co-direction by Angus MacLane, and its screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code is a method for transmitting text information using on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understandable by skilled individuals without special equipment. Its design varies character length inversely to frequency of occurrence in English to increase communication speed. Less sensitive to poor signal conditions than voice, it remains comprehensible to humans without a decoding device. In emergencies, Morse code can be sent by improvised methods, making it one of the simplest and most versatile telecommunication methods.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born on March 16, 1986, is an American actress.

A 6.5 magnitude earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12, 2005, at 21:47 (UTC), in the Hindu Kush region. The Hindu Kush is an 800 km mountain range stretching near the Afghan-Pakistan border, from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, known for its high snow-capped peaks. Its highest point is Tirich Mir (or Terichmir) at 7708 m in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, and it was historically known as the Caucasus Indicus or Paropamisadae in Ancient Greek.
As of 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin had a student body of approximately 840, with most students residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand name encompassing various sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and other media globally, which are either controlled or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch's family. Rupert Murdoch, as Chairman and CEO, had full control of News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the conglomerate split on June 28, 2013. The Murdoch family owns both 21st Century Fox and News Corp through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a US-based women's apparel company that features clothing with a tomboyish style.
Bessie Smith, born April 15, 1894, and died September 26, 1937, was an American blues singer.

Speech recognition (SR) is an inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics focused on developing methodologies and technologies for computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text, drawing upon knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.
Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and dying on 1 December 1947, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that premiered on BBC One on 8 March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, was released on 20 October 1995. The film was shot in India, London, and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director, while Tim Roth, born December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and only remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band, Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is an actor who won two Academy Awards for his roles in the mystery drama Mystic River (2003) and the biopic Milk (2008). He made his film debut in Taps (1981) and had a diverse range of roles in the 1980s, including Fast Times at Ridgemont High. Penn garnered critical attention for films like At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way, and became known as a prominent leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), for which he earned his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received additional Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001). His fourth feature film, the biographical drama survival movie Into the Wild (2007), also garnered critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

Volcanic outgassing likely formed Earth's primordial atmosphere and ocean, which lacked oxygen and was toxic to modern life. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, allowing liquid water to exist on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape Earth's oceans, continents, and the species they contain. The biosphere, now largely influenced by human activity, significantly impacts the atmosphere and other surface systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, productive soils, and clean air and water. Water covers 71% of the Earth's surface.
Nuuk is the capital and largest city of Greenland and the municipality of Sermersooq.

How to Train Your Dragon 2 is written and directed by Dean DeBlois. The film features the returning voice cast of Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig, with new additions Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington. Cate Blanchett voices Valka and Djimon Hounsou voices Drago.

"Down with Love" refers to two distinct productions: a 2003 romantic comedy film and a TV series. The film, directed by Peyton Reed and written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, stars ReneÌe Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce, serving as a pastiche of 1960s sex comedies, particularly those starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson. The TV series, also titled "Down with Love," was broadcast in Taiwan on China Television (CTV) from January 31, 2010, to May 23, 2010, and on Gala Television (GTV) from February 2, 2010, to May 30, 2010.
Paris is an album by Paris Hilton, and its production incorporates elements from other genres, including reggae, soul, and pop rock.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman, starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. The film featured John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold in their first significant film roles, and also included early career appearances by Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle MonÃ¡e Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer recognized for her song "Love or Lust," which was featured in Bill Duke's film Deep Cover. She is also known for contributing choruses to numerous classic West Coast rap songs, including Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride."

The University of Mississippi has 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent of its overall student body from Mississippi, with 23 percent being minorities, and international students representing 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions, and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, she co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime series Unreal, and is currently starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren (December 5, 1782 â July 24, 1862) was an American politician and member of the Democratic Party who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. He also held senior roles under Andrew Jackson, including eighth Vice President from 1833 to 1837 and tenth Secretary of State from 1829 to 1831. Van Buren was a key supporter and organizer for Jackson in the 1828 election, running for Governor of New York to aid Jackson's campaign before resigning after two months to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, his resignation as Secretary of State helped resolve the Petticoat affair, after which Jackson appointed him as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to Rutgers University -- Camden, which was founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. It is the tenth most populous of the 50 United States and has the 11th most extensive total area, making it the largest state by total area east of the Mississippi River. Michigan is the only state to consist of two peninsulas, which results in it being one of the leading U.S. states for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionised publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive paperbacks, sold for sixpence through Woolworths and other high street stores, which brought high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction to the mass market.
The 2008 film "Australia" had its production take place in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who helped make country music a worldwide phenomenon. "Excuse My French" is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana, and it is also a 2014 Egyptian film Comedy directed by Amr Salama. The film is based on Salama's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia and was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board, requiring Salama to adjust the script while preserving its core concept of religious discrimination.
In 2013, Derek Hough starred in the independent dance film Make Your Move, which was a South Korean-American production inspired by Romeo and Juliet.

"Bad Romance" is a song by American singer Lady Gaga from her 2009 extended play, The Fame Monster. It was showcased at Alexander McQueen's show at Paris Fashion Week in October 2009, following an illegal demo leak, and achieved worldwide success by topping charts and selling 12 million copies, becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. Separately, "Bad Romance" (film), titled Les Mauvais Romans, is a 2011 independent drama film.

DreamWorks Animation is a studio that has released 34 feature films, including the franchises Shrek, its prequel-spinoff Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, as well as other hits like Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. The studio also produced the American computer-animated fantasy television series Trollhunters for Netflix, which was created by Guillermo del Toro and co-produced with Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank (born 8 August 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr. (born 18 September 1989), is also a British professional boxer, holding the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, and previously the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News, and previously held full control as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, which split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013, becoming the world's second-largest media conglomerate. His younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch, is an Australian, British, American businessman, the chief executive officer of 21st Century Fox, and chairman of Sky plc.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/model in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with most of her income derived from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, informally abbreviated to Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are typically detected by a radiographic examination, also known as an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large region located in south Wales that contains abundant coal deposits, particularly within the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental football club competition organized by CONCACAF for the top football clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, originally known as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when first organized in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother after George's death in 1936, when her eldest son, Edward, ascended the throne, but he abdicated later the same year to marry Wallis Simpson. She supported her second son, Albert, who became George VI, until his death in 1952. She died the following year, during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
The film Poseidon grossed $181,674,817 at the worldwide box office against a budget of $160 million.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first presented at the 1996 ceremony, and Omar Epps and Joe Morton currently share the record for the most wins, each having received the award three times.

Human trafficking involves the trade of humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimated in 2014 that forced labor alone, a component of human trafficking, generates approximately $150 billion in annual profits. Of those exploited, 14.2 million (68%) were for labor, 4.5 million (22%) for sexual exploitation, and 2.2 million (10%) for state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 film, which had a sequel titled Rio 2, released on April 11, 2014.

Peking University (PKU, BeÌidaÌ) is a major Chinese research university located in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, replacing the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, it was the first modern national university established in China and also served as the highest administration for education at its founding. PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, which included his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice, and his distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming has significant effects on humans, including the threat to food security caused by decreasing crop yields and the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.
"Australia" is a 2008 Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore includes songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making. Folklore encompasses oral traditions like tales, proverbs, and jokes.

The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films, which were recognized for being both informative and entertaining. Additionally, the unit was responsible for training combat cameramen.

James Jones (author) won the 1952 National Book Award for "From Here to Eternity," which was adapted for film and television. James Jones (basketball player) averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships, reached the NBA Finals for the seventh consecutive year with LeBron James in 2017, finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-08 season, and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999 as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process used for generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, with the resignation becoming effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor known for his portrayal of the fourth incarnation of the Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, a tenure longer than any other actor, and for narrating the comedy series Little Britain. Beyond acting roles, Baker has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site has a cleanup project and also hosts the Columbia Generating Station, a commercial nuclear power plant. Additionally, it is home to various centers for scientific research and development, such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official primarily responsible for acting as spokesperson for the executive branch of the U.S. government administration, particularly concerning the President, senior executives, and policies. This position is filled by presidential appointment and does not require U.S. Senate advice and consent. Despite being a non-Cabinet post, it is very prominent due to frequent media briefings that inform the public.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" due to bluegrass in its fertile pastures, features the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, home to Louisville and Lexington. The state is also recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film featuring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, who also starred in The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of Despacito were released: an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television, with Starrcade (1985) airing live this way, and eventually transitioned to pay-per-view television, becoming the first NWA event to do so from 1987. In 2014, the WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983-1986), which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside the pay-per-view events, rating the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence, particularly the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum, T.A. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for a service and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played football as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League (NFL) for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

"Excuse My French" refers to both the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian film Comedy directed by Amr Salama, which is based on Salama's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or disk, is a type of disk storage composed of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium. This medium is sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric that removes dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, followed by a bloody civil war from 1960 to 1996 between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, which included genocidal massacres of the Maya population perpetrated by the military.
Forceps are a handheld, hinged instrument used for grasping and holding objects, and outside medicine, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The series "The Closer" began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after its sixth season concluded as cable's highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, a fictional character and protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, is played by Matthew Fox. Lost is an American television drama series that aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes, with its first season averaging an estimated 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey, an American actor born November 4, 1969, has preferred dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, Free State of Jones, and Mud. The 2012 film Mud stars Matthew McConaughey, Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer (writer) is best known for his books, including Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine, his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band The Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, born April 9, 1912, and died January 27, 1986, was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He is best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in March 1941. Gutzon Borglum created the sculpture's design and oversaw its execution from 1927-1941 with the help of his son, Lincoln Borglum, who then took over as leader of the construction project.

The film "Underdog" was directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents provided by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, as they return to Earth from a space habitat called "The Ark" after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin, Marcus Kane, and Thelonious Jaha, who are Clarke's mother, a council member on the Ark, and the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father, respectively.

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite being initially marred by financial problems due to its pioneering nature, is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project. It generated both awareness and considerable funds, while also providing valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent projects, notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is cited by the media as one of India's influential filmmakers, widely credited with revolutionising the Tamil film industry and altering the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas on August 27, 1858, at the second of the seven Lincoln-Douglas Debates in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, featured Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. Debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracted large audiences from neighboring states due to the monumental importance of slavery to citizens nationwide.

Easy A, stylized as easy A, is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. It stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. Her writing career began in 1976 with "Interview with the Vampire" while she lived in California, and she started writing sequels in the 1980s, gaining popularity with critics and readers after initial mixed reactions to her early works. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 at the 2010 United States Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population consisted mostly of European immigrants. A city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film, The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader. The Canyons is an original work and was critically derided.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. These debates took place in seven towns within the state of Illinois.

Homer is the name ancient Greeks ascribed to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are the central works of ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle, born April 8, 1974, and died February 2, 2013, was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band consisting of Soundgarden's Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07), having started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founding Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, Wilk plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, includes Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle MonÃ¡e Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin, published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. The University of Mississippi has about 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent overall coming from Mississippi, with 23 percent being minorities, and international students originating from 90 nations.
Flaked was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with its premiere scheduled for June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly (1784-1785, 1798-1799), served as New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), and was a U.S. senator from New York (1791-1797), ultimately reaching the apex of his career as vice president.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau for the Soviet space programme, succeeding the Voskhod spacecraft and originally built for Soviet manned lunar programs, remaining in service today. The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch these spacecraft, conducting 8 unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned launches. The name Soyuz means "Union," as in "Soviet Union."
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine experienced a breakup when de la Rocha quit due to growing tensions, leading him to a solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, recording three albums before disbanding in 2007. The same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited, performing at Coachella in April 2007, their first show in seven years. Their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one such company, listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, and is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (SRV), is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. With an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, it is the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous Asian country. It is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world, achieving the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies in 2011. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film that was written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary known for two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India. His execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, and he became a popular folk hero after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's "Dangal," a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (James Stuart), born 19 June 1566 and died 27 March 1625, reigned as King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death, following the union of the Scottish and English crowns. Although he ruled both kingdoms in personal union, Scotland and England remained individual sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James was a major advocate for a single parliament for England and Scotland and faced many difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack, born December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was an original core cast member of Shortland Street and is known for her roles as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her other works include the film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and her portrayal of Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Her most notable recent work was starring as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years, leaving the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, primarily recognized for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received generally mixed reviews from music critics but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies, becoming Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States and selling 757,000 copies. Artpop was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies worldwide.
Stadium Arcadium, released in 2006, was John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, and the group's last to feature him. Frusciante confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. A controversial figure, she is lauded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, despite ongoing arguments over Thatcherism.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his musical career, McKagan is also a writer, having penned weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has performed acting roles and narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative centre. It is also Spain's third largest metropolitan area, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain, and its capital, Valencia, is the third largest city and metropolitan area in the country.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
It was announced on April 26, 2012, that the series Make It or Break It had ended, with its third season being the final one, and the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies enabling computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text, incorporating knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Its applications include voice user interfaces like voice dialing and call routing, domotic appliance control, search, simple data entry, structured document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft (Direct Voice Input). Advances in SR are evidenced by academic papers and the worldwide industry adoption of deep learning methods by players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, many of whom base their core technology on deep learning.

Richard Alf (1952-2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. The San Diego Comic-Con was founded in 1970 as the Golden State Comic Book Convention by a group of San Diegans including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later called the "San Diego Comic Book Convention".
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which featured Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied at 16 under par, while McIlroy and Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat are at 15 under par. McIlroy carded a third straight 67, including an eagle on the 12th, as he seeks his first title since May, despite dropping shots on the 3rd and 10th before recovering with a birdie and another eagle. Having ruptured a ligament in his left ankle in July, McIlroy returned to play in the US PGA, FedEx Cup play-offs, and the Frys.com Open, and is now targeting a third Race to Dubai title, leading England's Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining. English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland are in fifth and seventh place respectively, at 13 and 12 under par.

Sheikh Ali Salman stated that meaningful national dialogue requires the government to offer "concrete solutions" and a royal family representative, identifying Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist amidst hardliners who oppose dialogue. Salman welcomed the dialogue, acknowledging that while many young protesters have lost faith, working with reformists like the Crown Prince is the only way forward, recalling a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy agreed with the Crown Prince that was severed by GCC troops. He expressed hope that US Secretary of State John Kerry would exert more pressure for human rights and democratic practices than his predecessor, and criticized the UK government for only privately urging reform, calling for public statements. Al-Wefaq will continue "peaceful demonstrations" despite bans and called for the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders and human rights activists, stating their participation is crucial for the dialogue's success.

Hogwood, an influential exponent of the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home following an illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents, and the AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah was named among the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held various positions including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and professorships at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Tributes described him as a great ambassador for historically informed music, a natural academic, incredibly clever, and a genial person who left a fantastic legacy.

In the year to the end of March, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous 12 months, marking the lowest figure since 1976 and half that of nine years ago, with only one case from 2015-16 unresolved as of March 31, 2016. Sharp instruments, predominantly knives, were the most common method, accounting for 51% of homicides, and 31% of the accused were identified as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline but emphasized the need for continued efforts in education, enforcement, community support, and challenging alcohol misuse and casual violence, while Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautioned against previous upward revisions of figures and highlighted a 45-year high in sexual crime and a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault. The 2014-15 homicide figure was initially 59 but later revised to 62.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland on Saturday, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win this season. Dan Gosling scored for The Cherries, giving them the lead and ending a three-game goal drought, but Sunderland secured the win with goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Despite Sunderland being reduced to 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, The Cherries could not find an equalizer. Manager Howe stated that the loss should not be attributed to a lack of confidence, referencing their previous six goals against Hull, and expressed frustration over the team's inability to convert numerous chances, emphasizing the importance of moving forward.

Mr Abbott stated that the only way to prevent deaths at sea was to "stop the boats," a policy Australia uses to detain migrants in offshore processing camps, which the New York Times described as "brutal," "inhumane, of dubious legality," and warned European leaders against adopting. Mr Abbott reiterated his stance, saying Australia had stopped illegal boats. Separately, Mr Abbott angered Australian Jewish groups by claiming Islamic State was worse than the Nazis because IS boasts about its evil, while Nazis tried to hide theirs. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry called this comment "injudicious and unfortunate," highlighting the fundamental difference between terrorism and state-implemented genocide, and stating IS crimes cannot be compared to the systematic mass murder by Nazis, though Mr Abbott later stood by his comments while clarifying he was not "ranking evil."

The United States suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia aimed at sustaining the cessation of hostilities, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians, targeting critical infrastructure like hospitals, and preventing humanitarian aid, including the 19 September attack on a humanitarian aid convoy. Russia regretted the US decision, denying involvement in the convoy attack and accusing Washington of shifting blame for the collapse of last month's truce, stating the US failed to fulfill key conditions such as improving humanitarian conditions around Aleppo and separating jihadist groups from the moderate opposition. Aleppo, Syria's largest city, has experienced heavy aerial bombardment since the ceasefire ended two weeks ago, resulting in hundreds of deaths and trapping approximately 250,000 people in its eastern part. Despite the suspension, the two sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.
DID NOT RECIEIVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases and 83 hospitalizations since November. While laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, the main cause of his death has not yet been established, and an inquest will be opened for further tests. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash before his death, which occurred the morning after he saw a GP for the rash. His family is unaware how he contracted measles, as no close family members, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence on a boy under the age of 16, which was reported to have occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

A football match between Gateshead and Guiseley ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley, who are unbeaten in five matches, took the lead on 15 minutes when Jake Lawlor scored from a James Hurst assist. Gateshead, who are unbeaten in nine National League matches, equalized on 62 minutes with a goal from Wes York, following a slip by half-time substitute Derek Asamoah. During the game, Gateshead's Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston's effort, and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted saved a shot from Wesley York. Gus Mafuta of Gateshead and Simon Walton of Guiseley received yellow cards, and several substitutions were made for both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, intends to replace two stands to increase capacity, an alternative to delayed new stadium proposals at Ashton Vale. This work was approved by Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the club would proceed. The club will sign the section 106 agreement, followed by a six-week judicial review period, with redevelopment plans set to begin in May if no judicial review occurs by March.

Cuadrilla suspended shale gas drilling, known as "fracking," as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, and will examine data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume. Fracking involves shattering underground shale rocks to release gas, and the BGS noted that the latest tremor and an earlier one on April 1 shared a "similar location and mechanism," stating that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause fracturing and earthquakes. While controversial in the US due to environmental concerns, the Commons energy select committee supports it in the UK, believing tight regulation can overcome issues. Cuadrilla expects analysis and consultation to take weeks, and the latest quake was felt in Poulton-Le-Fylde, with its epicentre within 2km of the Preese Hall site at a depth of approximately 2km.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after denying three counts. The conviction stemmed from an incident in April 2015 when he played with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes, giving the impression he was collecting cash for the campaign, according to Sgt Chris Gaynor. Carpenter, who was cleared of two other counts, stated in his defence that he was simply busking and the banner was a tribute, not an attempt to deceive, despite having piped for the charity previously. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, confirmed he had given Carpenter permission to display the banner but not to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter is scheduled to be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney after a QPR keeper error, and Tom Lawrence. Despite previously struggling to score, Ipswich created numerous chances, while QPR offered little in attack, only hitting the post late on. This victory lifted Ipswich four places to 14th, moving them above QPR, who dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy expressed satisfaction with the comprehensive win and his team's improved confidence, while QPR boss Ian Holloway lamented a "calamity" second goal and his players' lack of mental toughness, though he defended his goalkeeper.

Wells, 23, impressed in the T20 Blast last season by scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction, noting that the elite performance environment created by the coaches motivates players to be part of it.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12, with Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams particularly praised for their leadership and high tackle count. Looking ahead, the Reds will face seven teams below them in the table and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games. Coach Churcher acknowledged that the Chinnor performance, though emotionally dogged, was not complete and stressed the importance of building on it.

Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a 28-year-old allegedly Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested in Kolkata for the alleged rape of a 74-year-old nun, marking the sixth arrest in the case. Police acted on a tip-off that Nazu, identified from CCTV footage and having fled to Bangladesh, was returning by train. Five previously arrested suspects named Nazrul as the rapist. Milon Sarkar was arrested in May as the alleged gang leader, though his specific role was unclear. The incident, which occurred on March 14 in Ranaghat town, involved money being stolen from the convent school, the building ransacked, and the nun raped in the convent, causing widespread outrage and protests across India.

This interactive video, featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains key reasons for changes in consumer buying habits, such as the impact of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports on UK consumers. It also explores how the ownership and ranking of major UK brands are evolving. A non-interactive version of the content is available, and the passage provides links to extra information including China's ownership, freezing food tips, and a survey of top UK consumer brands.

Two women were defrauded by individuals impersonating BT employees; a 71-year-old from Sandyhills on September 15, and another woman in Stranraer seven days later. In the Stranraer incident, the caller claimed to be from BT technical support, gained remote access to her computer, and took money. PC Siobhan Pellett highlighted the frightening ease with which these fraudsters gain computer access and the substantial sums taken, advising people to be very careful with cold calls requesting remote access for alleged faults. The police emphasized that individuals should never provide banking details or account numbers over the telephone, as reputable businesses do not ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has joined the third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions, where he was replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the Super 8 Qualifiers, with chairman Mark Campbell praising his work at Swinton. Duffy previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during a 16-year career.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach, near Kenfig Nature Reserve, at 12:50 GMT on Sunday, where a rider was found with head injuries and very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand. The rider was treated before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, a decision made at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC) by representatives from over 160 countries. This new system, organized by the UN's International Telecommunication Union (ITU), aims to improve upon current ground-based radar systems and address weaknesses exposed by the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014. It will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, allowing for real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world and covering the approximately 70% of global airspace currently uncovered. The UN's aviation arm, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will require aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in August 2002, has been found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested in Ohio after the FBI received a tip on October 30, following problems Julian had applying for college. The FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children confirmed Julian's identity, and his mother has been notified. Bobby Hernandez is charged with kidnapping and tampering with records for obtaining a driver's license in 2012, and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected his father around the time of the boy's disappearance when he fled after taking his son to pre-school.

A fire on 2 March at a Duncan Street site, run by Asset and Land Group and operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, caused train service reductions and travel delays. Following the blaze, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the firm from accepting waste and later decided to revoke its environmental permit, effective 7 August, though the company can appeal and is still required to remove all waste. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) stated the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, despite nine visits in the last year, and had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential fire impacts, leading to joint visits and the EA's enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills directly linked to the situation in Ukraine, particularly concerning Crimea. One bill would allow a territory to join the Russian Federation based on a referendum or leaders' plea, especially if a neighboring state is "disintegrating," bypassing the current requirement for a treaty. This is relevant to Crimea, where pro-Russian sentiment and Russian citizens are prevalent, and follows Russia's actions in Abkhazia and South Ossetia after the 2008 Georgia war. The second bill aims to fast-track Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speaking individuals, by waiving state tax, previous residence, and financial requirements, and allowing them to retain Ukrainian citizenship. This procedure would allow applications at Russian diplomatic missions before August 1st, with citizenship granted in two months instead of a year, and is presented as support for "fraternal people of Ukraine" against a "brown threat."

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant slump, aiming for modest grid positions despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. The decline began in 2013 with chassis design issues, and while the car has since improved, the Honda power-unit is now the primary problem, contrasting sharply with their highly successful past partnership with Honda in 1988. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, including periods of domination and scandals like 'spy-gate' in 2007 and 'lie-gate' in 2009. Ron Dennis, who previously led the team to success, returned to control after the disastrous 2013 season, insisting that success, including breaking Mercedes' current dominance, will return. Alonso rejoined in 2015, believing the renewed Honda partnership offered his best chance for a third title, and the team maintains that the car is strong and the Honda engine will improve next year, leading to future championships, though this remains a matter of belief.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was found badly injured after being shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January, dying later in hospital. He was shot while getting into his car after leaving Phoenix Gym, with detectives believing those involved had waited for about an hour. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and one 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at speed and are urging people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward with information.

The passage describes five ways to engage with Christmas online, blending spirituality with digital platforms. Everyday Church Online provides virtual Sunday services with streamed sermons and a chat room, reaching a global congregation from 61 countries, and features a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon called "The Hope Awakens." Guardians of Ancora is a free-to-play fantasy game for 8-11 year olds, developed by Scripture Union, where players rediscover Bible stories, including special Christmas quests about the birth of Jesus. Viral.de's "The Digital Story of Nativity" is a successful 2010 video that tells the nativity story through social media updates, viewed nearly six million times. The Churches Advertising Network's video "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle," which depicts a modern couple transforming into Mary and Joseph, has about 250,000 views but was rejected by cinemas for being "too religious." Next Manga has launched app and e-book versions of its Manga-style Old Testament stories, including "Manga Messiah" for the nativity, available in 33 languages, with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees. Additionally, many Christian groups utilize platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with communities, aiming to offer spiritual reflections.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, offering 320 hectares of replacement land.
