She offered 100,000 rubles (Â£1,400) and was filmed by an undercover police officer, posing as a hitman, detailing her desire for Vanya to suffer unbearable pain, including broken arms and legs and damaged kidneys, before she would "finish" him. Simonova was arrested in her car after handing over expense money and now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief, hoping they "throw away the key" for her prison cell.

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho, 52 and a father-of-two, has a strong faith, talking to God daily and praying only for personal matters, never about football. He never discusses the game with his wife and strives to separate his professional and family life. Mourinho believes he is a good person, a good family man, and a good friend, despite his professional persona. He also revealed that he and his family understand poverty and have worked as ambassadors against hunger with the World Food Programme.

On April 1, Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, returned to the show for the first time in eight years. The 91-year-old handled the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before turning hosting duties over to Drew Carey, and seemed to not miss a beat despite his absence.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday by the Metropolitan Police for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight, facing felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave from his post with the foreign missions branch. This arrest follows recent allegations of misconduct against a high-ranking supervisor and an incident where two officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking, marking the latest challenges for the agency.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion in Lahore's safari park. Saeed exited his car and crept to within 10 feet of the male lion, armed only with a camera. The clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, which aggressively jumped towards him, forcing Saeed to rapidly retreat and scramble back into his car. He described it as a very close encounter, stating he wanted to show the lion's character and status, but would not do it again.

New York City police have released an image of a distinctive heart tattoo with the name 'Monique' found on the right leg of an unnamed woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, in hopes of identifying her nearly a month after she died. The woman was discovered lying unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, and was pronounced dead that evening. She had no identification on her, and police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death, while asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Upon returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009 and unable to afford property, Hannah and Alex built a solar-powered, two-bedroom, wood and steel home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. This project took about a year and a half and cost approximately $25,000. They now live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand, with their home powered mostly by solar panels, water from a nearby spring, and gas for the stove and hot water, surrounded by nature.

Research indicates that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who do not, or those who use individual devices. Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University found that kindergarten children sharing iPads over an academic year scored approximately 30 points higher than students with their own devices or no iPads. This research, involving 352 students, suggests that "collaborative learning around the technology" is the key factor, prompting a recommendation for schools to reconsider tablet usage, especially in earlier grades, to maximize effectiveness. These findings are scheduled for presentation at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk and balance on its two front trotters, as shown in a heartwarming online video where it takes unsteady steps and forages for food. This piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', belongs to farmer Ms. Duan from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, China, and has attracted many villagers to see it. The piglet happily mixes with its siblings, all born with a full complement of legs, and remarkably regains its balance even when close to tipping over. This is not the first animal in China to gain fame for walking on two legs, as a rabbit at Liuzhou zoo also became a star attraction for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Dayle Coyne Racing's front-outside tire changer, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg at the infield care center and was subsequently released. Many cars struggled with traction due to pre-race rain, and Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and then shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the act, stating he was jealous of men looking at her, and had yelled at her that she was "a slut" and "a whore." Cicera, who went by the stage name Amanda Bueno, belonged to the dance troop Jaula das Gostozuedas. Severiano was arrested after crashing a stolen car during his getaway, and police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle; he now faces life in jail.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, known for "I Quit Sugar," has revealed her personal struggle with mental illness, specifically anxiety, which brought her to a point where she considered ending her life. During a candid interview, Wilson, 41, explained that a combination of mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family contributed to her feeling isolated and unable to see a way out. She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is vital to address the increasing rates of stress and anxiety affecting Australian women, noting that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." While she struggled in her younger years, feeling she had "missed out on a guide book to life," Wilson has recently found peace with being an "anxious person." Beyond Blue reports that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and one condition can often lead to the other.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant Oregon woman, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar when she found her using heroin in her bathroom and refused to leave. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage," citing Oregon law allowing physical force against intruders and the ex-girlfriend's history of harassment and attempts to draw the boyfriend back into addiction. Curtin, who gave birth in January, has since moved on from the relationship and is living with her parents, while the boyfriend is not involved in their child's life.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner, who attempted to trick her by including a broccoli spear. Gemma reacted with disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and then spit it out. The passage expresses hope that the two children she lives with do not follow her example regarding greens. Other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page, which occurred when the address for the young entrepreneur awards page, scrapped in 2011, was allowed to retire, leading a porn site to take over the URL. The bank removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, and apologized to the public for any inconvenience, while insisting its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were rescued from a house fire in Clinton on Sunday morning after Marcus called 911. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom, Marcus calmly provided instructions to firefighters during an 11-minute call, also soothing his sister. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window, handing Marcus out and giving Aaliyah a gas mask. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries, while three other family members who escaped on their own were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, identified as *Noctiluca scintillans*, is lighting up Australia's east coast, with amazing images captured in Jervis Bay, NSW. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight, caused by millions of plankton emitting light, as a "beautiful supernatural scene." A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales explained that this single-celled phytoplankton, which blossoms in spring and autumn, gives off the luminous glow as a defense mechanism, preying on diatoms.

New tests that pinpoint genetic markers in breast cancer tumours can determine their aggressiveness, potentially sparing patients chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened to assess the risk of recurrence, with some women showing a risk as low as five percent, comparable to or better than chemotherapy. While most women routinely receive chemotherapy after tumour removal to prevent recurrence, despite severe side effects, experts believe it may not be necessary for all. Tests like Endopredict allow patients with a low score to opt out of chemotherapy. These tests are mostly private, costing around Â£2,500, but specialists hope for NHS availability due to potential savings. Professor Kefah Mokbel notes these tests enable informed patient choice, as exemplified by Becca Cornford, who avoided chemotherapy after Endopredict showed a low recurrence risk.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious, with 18 other ships also experiencing emergency evacuations. A "no touching" rule at sea suggests these women conceived before boarding or during leave. This data follows an incident where Commander Sarah West was flown back to the UK amid claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013, and 102 women were evacuated from Iraq, all due to pregnancy, as strict military rules prohibit mothers-to-be from serving in war zones. Most of these pregnancies were conceived before deployment, though a small number may have occurred on tour, with pregnant personnel on operations being returned at the first convenient opportunity.

A drone carrying traces of a radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was discovered on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the non-immediately harmful radioactive material, was found on the same day a Japanese court approved restarting two nuclear reactors, a plan unpopular with many. This incident highlights a gap in Japanese law, which restricts drone flights around airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings, prompting officials to consider reviewing regulations to cope with the threat of drone terrorism.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him daily on his motorbike. He does this because he fears she will get lost if left alone, especially after his father passed away and his wife and son are unavailable to care for her. He secures her with a sash around both their waists for the 4km journey, which takes an hour, and his employers, a bank, have provided a room for her at his workplace. Lu Xincai feels it is his duty to care for her, as she cared for him when he was young.

Heavy drinking among Americans, including episodes of binge-drinking, increased by 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, primarily driven by rising rates among women. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking is four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion. Nationwide, the rate of binge drinking among women increased more than seven times the rate among men over the decade. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. This increase is attributed to changed social norms, making it more acceptable for women to drink, along with alcohol becoming cheaper, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. Alcohol was linked to 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and an estimated cost of over $220 billion annually. The study, the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, analyzed data from 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and babies at risk, and state the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to potential infections, complications, disability, or death. The rate of caesareans in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, now accounting for over a quarter of births, including a growing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. However, the World Health Organization (WHO) suggests the ideal rate should be between 10 and 15 percent, citing the dangers and costs involved, with a planned caesarean costing Â£2,369 compared to Â£1,665 for a natural birth. The WHO's stance contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow the procedure even without medical justification, such as for tokophobia, previous complicated births, women over 40, or those with conditions like asthma, diabetes, or depression, and previous research indicates that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' items in a yard sale. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her at his Edgartown property, estimated to be worth $800,000, sitting in his living room, after which she claimed ownership and fled when he called the police. Filkins was arrested later that day when she attempted to re-enter the home, and a construction worker reported seeing her with items from the home, appearing to have a yard sale. Missing items include deck chairs, a Weber grill, side tables, lamps, framed posters, various pots, pans, linens, and a painting. Police are asking anyone who received items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, noting that purchasers are also victims and can seek restitution. Filkins is scheduled to be in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after being handed in to Albury police station. Police officers, finding the phone unlocked, used Bella's Facebook page to post selfies and humorous photos of the phone in various locations, including a "holding cell," along with puns and advice to put a password on her phone, in an effort to track her down and inform her where to collect it. Bella, who lost her phone at a friend's birthday party, was unaware of the posts until she arrived at the station, where officers recognized her from her Facebook page. She found the situation humorous and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was mauled to death after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa. The helpless calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface by one of the brawling adults, while its mother watched in horror. Stacey Farrell, a tour operator, witnessed the event, noting that the mother had previously tried to protect the calf from other hippos. The baby hippo died hours later from its injuries.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for Â£575,000, a fraction of the price of neighboring homes, but it comes with only three years left on its lease and requires modernization. The cost over three years equates to Â£191,000 annually or Â£15,000 monthly, comparable to local rental rates. If a buyer extends the lease, the 1,990 sq/ft "unmodernised" maisonette, described as "bright and well proportioned," could be worth over Â£6 million, though a 90-year lease extension is estimated to cost between Â£3.35 and Â£4.5 million. This rare opportunity has generated significant interest, despite warnings from experts about the substantial premium required to extend the lease.

Starbucks announced that a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada has been resolved, with stores expected to open for business as usual on Saturday. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prevented staff from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales, leading baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods. While some stores accepted cash, many locations closed early or entirely to avoid giving away free products. This incident, which also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores, occurred one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training and radicalisation in rural areas of West Wales, specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. Those involved engage in seemingly ordinary community activities but possess ulterior motives. Islamic extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998, including a group sent by hate preacher Abu Hamza to train in the Brecon Beacons. Other incidents include two 7/7 bombers photographed in North Wales in 2005, three Cardiff men arrested in 2010 for an Al-Qaeda inspired plot, and Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Lee Rigby, having studied Arabic at a centre near Llanybydder, which DC Jones linked to a terrorist attack. Community intelligence is considered vital by authorities.

An Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct and only scientifically described in 2003, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in West Australia after tropical cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia, making the discovery highly significant for scientists due to the limited knowledge about the species. Identified through DNA profiling, the 5.68m juvenile female provides an opportunity to learn more about its regional distribution and improve identification guides. Typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like those of Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, Omura's whales possess a sleek body, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, with its skeleton to be recovered later for further scientific investigation and potential public display.

The passage discusses the debate surrounding presidential candidates' hormones, particularly the view that a woman's hormones might make her unfit for leadership, as expressed by Cheryl Rios regarding Hillary Clinton. However, the text counters this by noting that male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' decision-making and studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks, with Time magazine even suggesting a postmenopausal woman is "biologically primed" to lead. The underlying issue is identified as pervasive gender bias against women in the workplace and leadership, which limits their potential despite their achievements in education and the workforce. This bias is evident in various forms, from corporate board representation to how male and female professors are perceived. The passage concludes that eradicating gender stereotypes and achieving equality is crucial, as it benefits everyone, leading to stronger companies, families, and overall societal well-being.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling over 200 items from his antique collection in a Â£100,000 auction due to downsizing his home. The collection, which reflects his keen interest in military history and medieval longbows, includes a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow, furniture, paintings, and books, with the auction being held this Saturday by Dominic Winter Auctioneers. Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and playing Winston Churchill, and an expert on the longbow who studied with J.R.R. Tolkien, expressed sadness at parting with his treasured possessions but hopes they bring joy to their new owners, and despite retiring from stage acting, he intends to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, and has been on the run since Saturday. His mother was found dead at their shared Winter Garden home, with foul play determined, on the same day Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son. He is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was previously committed for attempted suicide; his mother was helping him through a divorce. Neighbors believe divorce proceedings and recent bad news may have triggered him, and his mother reportedly prevented him from attending the visit to avoid further court trouble. The murder weapon has been found, but the cause of death is not confirmed, and Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships by the International Association of Athletics Federations Council. This decision bypassed the usual bidding process, as the council saw it as a "unique strategic opportunity to host the IAAF World Championships for the first time in the USA." Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, but a recent presentation persuaded the IAAF. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated that this strategic decision enables them to take advantage of a unique opportunity involving public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public, aiming to access a key market and develop the sport globally. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, after luring him to his death in a honey trap to steal his winnings. Granger befriended Hassan after spotting him flashing money at a casino, then left his flat door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, 29, to enter. The two men tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home for his hidden cash, fleeing with Â£3,000, his TV, and mobile phone. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, robbery, and conspiracy to falsely imprison, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder, robbery, and conspiracy to falsely imprison, receiving life sentences with a minimum of 36 years. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by Judge William Kennedy.

Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a customary second-half-of-the-season slump, with his form significantly dipping since Christmas, as evidenced by his poor performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. This trend was also noted by his former club Barcelona, which observed a downward trend in his stats each season. After a brilliant start where he accumulated 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he has only managed four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015, making it unlikely he will break Thierry Henry's assist record of 20. Despite his happiness playing regularly, the intense campaign is taking its toll, raising questions about his durability. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is concerned about Fabregas's fatigue and declining impact, but hopes for a late-season resurgence to help secure the Premier League title.

West Ham are discussing a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed coaches during a two-week trial with their academy and is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean, also having offers from Belgian clubs. Meanwhile, West Ham have revealed season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as Â£289, representing the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League, in an effort to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, despite a wealth of evidence including video, names, and car registration numbers. Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, kicked in the head, and suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss during an incident at Everleigh, near Amesbury, while chasing an artificial scent. Lane and others condemned the police decision as "pathetic" and "disgraceful," feeling let down, while police stated the inquiry was stopped due to insufficient evidence but could be re-opened if new information comes to light. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece and chief English-language propagandist for al Qaeda, was killed in January in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation, though he was not specifically targeted. Also known as Azzam the American and Abu Suhayb, Gadahn was born in 1978, grew up in California, converted to Islam in 1995, and left the U.S. for Pakistan in 1998. He appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos, threatening attacks, urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests, criticizing U.S. presidents, and advocating for lone-wolf attacks. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda and was on the FBI's "most wanted terrorists" list. He also made recommendations for al Qaeda's media strategy. In a likely separate operation, fellow U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq was killed, along with U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies, and a new basketball superstar, five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, is gaining attention through a viral video. Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old, displays dazzling skills such as scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, which have earned him legions of fans across China. Netizens are stunned by his potential, with some questioning the authenticity of the video or expressing shame about their own basketball abilities in comparison.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalise child sex and incest in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for 'corrupting public morals', attended a Hacked Off rally chaired by John Cleese on February 25 in the Houses of Parliament to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off campaigns for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson inquiry, and O'Carroll's backing is an embarrassment to the group, though a spokesman stated the meeting was open to the public.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, displacing daily lap swimmers. Headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, Ten Pieces showcased a monochrome capsule collection of ten unisex items, designed to be worn in 20 different ways for day to night wear. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall with an ocean backdrop, while guests enjoyed nibbles and drinks on an unseasonably warm day, with beachgoers and passers-by also observing the event.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan enjoyed a family trip to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in northern California, with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, where he posed with and fed a rare white tiger, and also posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation over his opponent despite pressure to fight British rival Kell Brook in June.

The name of Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, was placed on an Israeli memorial at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His family, particularly his father Hussein Abu Khdeir, objected to his inclusion, refusing his son's name to be listed among "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor, an organization representing terror victims, also opposed his inclusion, describing his death as a "rogue attack" and stating he was not a terror victim. Following these complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial, will remove Abu Khdeir's name, and it has already been removed from the organization's website.

California-based YouTube user Lionel Hutz filmed his young son repeatedly chasing the family cat around the garden, attempting to use its belly as a pillow for rest. The cat initially tolerated this briefly before moving to new spots, with the boy following and repeating the action, until the cat eventually went indoors. A later video showed the duo had made up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Witness Robert Kushner lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying in a Philadelphia police corruption trial about his years selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, is one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government, alleging that some undercover officers on trial stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. This history was unknown to the academy, as Kushner had passed a background check when hired in 2010, despite his 2007 charges being expunged, a 2011 arrest resulting in probation, and a 2008 DUI guilty plea. Kushner stated he never meant to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges, describing 2007 as a "bad phase." Lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering claim the government's case relies on "19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop."

An explosion at a controversial paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province, specifically in Zhangzhou city, injured six people and sparked a huge fire. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, with five of the injured suffering from broken glass and sent to the hospital. Over 600 firefighters brought the blaze under control, while residents reported hearing the explosion and feeling tremors. This plant, which produces a reportedly carcinogenic chemical, had a previous explosion in July 2013 and was relocated from Xiamen in 2007 due to public protests and pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland under 21 international, is renowned for wearing his socks low, just above his shinpads, due to a lifelong superstition, and he uses children's shinpads. Despite referees telling him to pull his socks up, he refuses to change this habit. Grealish recently made his first Premier League start for the club in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing pleasure at the opportunity and hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Houston stated that Brown can live in this condition for a lifetime, does not respond to visitors or voices, and has a tracheostomy. This contradicts earlier remarks from her father, Bobby Brown, who said she was awake. However, an attorney for the Brown family, Christopher Brown, confirmed her condition has improved, doctors expect her to have a long life, and she has begun a rehabilitation process, though the quality of her life remains uncertain for years. Bobby Brown's wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, added that Bobbi Kristina has left the ICU, opened her eyes, and started rehabilitation.

Russia holds a 2-0 lead over Germany in the Fed Cup tie, placing them on the brink of reaching the final. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova secured a victory against Sabine Lisicki (4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3) after saving a match point, following Svetlana Kuznetsova's straight-sets win over Julia Goerges. Russia now needs one more win from Sunday's three matches to advance to the final and potentially claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008. Pavlyuchenkova noted Lisicki's power, while Lisicki commented on the match point and tiebreaker. Both players experienced serving difficulties, with Pavlyuchenkova recording 13 double faults and Lisicki 63 unforced errors.

Residents of New South Wales are warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm, potentially an east coast low, is predicted to hit later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. This comes as the State Emergency Service (SES) is still working to complete over 4,000 jobs from last week's wild weather and is concerned the new storm will hamper clean-up efforts, especially in the hard-hit Hunter region. While similar to last week's system, meteorologists suggest this event might be further from the coast and move faster, with the heaviest impacts expected in the state's far northern parts, including the northern rivers and mid north coasts, rather than Sydney. The community is urged to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss.

Nina Moric, a model from Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide, stating she was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure from a domestic accident where she fell and hit her head. She posted photographs of her bruising on Instagram, reassuring her followers that she was recovering at home and that the suicide claims were incorrect. While Italian media reported her mother found her and her boyfriend initially suggested she tried to commit suicide, Moric explicitly denied any intention to end her life, expressing shock at the claims. Italian media had also previously reported a suicide attempt by Moric in 2009. The passage also mentions her past marriage to paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmail, and their son.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a new poll reveals the British public's preferences for the baby's name and gender. Diana is the favorite name if the baby is a girl, with 12 percent of people questioned choosing it, followed by Alice and Charlotte at nine percent each. If the child is a boy, James is the top choice with 13 percent, and Alexander is second. Many people are hoping for a girl, with a quarter of 2,200 polled wanting a female baby, while only three percent hoped for a boy. Additionally, 68 percent of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday around 10 a.m. local time, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker. The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied his group was responsible for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after his representative confirmed he rejected the club's final contract offer. Alves has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, but has been unable to agree a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, stated that negotiations are over, as her client rejected a three-year contract extension offer that was contingent on him participating in 60 per cent of matches.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes the duo would be a perfect fit for the team due to their "south-american style" and abilities, and that the fans at La Bombonera would "go absolutely crazy" for them. He has played with both Pirlo, a popular midfielder, and Totti, a Roma legend, previously.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, in the 4:20 pm race at Wincanton, which made him an internet sensation with hundreds of thousands of online views. Despite the dramatic fall, Ferguson sustained only a cut on his nose and is undeterred, having already returned to riding out and mucking out stables as usual. He described the incident as a blur, feeling lucky to have avoided serious injury, and even gained Twitter followers and received banter from other jockeys.

James Haskell, London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man to promote the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie, which premiered at Westfield London shopping centre. Haskell returned to Wasps in 2012, having previously played for Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders after leaving Wasps in 2009. He first joined Wasps in 2002, playing eight seasons and earning his first England cap in 2007, and since his return, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and accumulated 57 England caps.

The wide leg trouser is a prominent SS15 trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans and making a comeback since the seventies. It comes in various styles, including denim, cropped, printed, or striped. To wear them successfully, especially for shorter individuals, the key is the shoe: high heels, particularly those with an exposed top of the foot, help elongate the leg. It's also recommended to keep the top half simple with a knit, shirt, or tee to maintain proportion and avoid being overwhelmed by fabric. For longer lengths, a high-waisted and very long style can give extra leg length. Denim is considered the easiest way to embrace the trend, with designers like Gucci showcasing flared jeans, while Celine and Stella McCartney offered dressier styles. Topshop also provides a high street version, the Miller jean. This trend updates a wardrobe and is suitable for spring regardless of the weather.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of "American Sniper" despite initial objections from over 200 students who felt the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and its people. The film portrays Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, who was fatally shot in 2013. Following a backlash and a counter-petition, E. Royster Harper, the university's vice president for student life, stated that canceling the showing was a mistake inconsistent with the university's value on freedom of expression, and the show will go on. As an alternative, umix will offer a screening of "Paddington," and the announcement drew praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly tried to set a quokka alight on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3, by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to contact the animal. The quokka, which is the size of a domestic cat and found on small islands off the west Australian coast, survived the reckless incident but was singed. Detectives questioned the two men, aged 18 and 24, who were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty, and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

102-year-old former dancer Alice Barker, who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s alongside figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen herself dance on film, as her motion pictures and memorabilia were lost. Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers compiled "soundies" (early music videos) featuring her, which they showed to her at her nursing home, delighting her with the opportunity to finally see herself dancing.

The art of washing one's own car is declining in Britain, with a third of men and three-quarters of women admitting they never wash their own motor, preferring to take it to a car wash. A survey of 1,100 adults by OSV found 31 per cent of men have never washed their car, and only 12 per cent of those who do, do it regularly. Factors contributing to this decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football, the rise of hand car washes, and vehicles like 4x4s being too large to clean. Only five per cent of those surveyed had ever asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. While Brits are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, with an estimated 15 million cars cleaned during the recent Easter break, one in four did it as an excuse to leave the house. Cars are most likely to be washed by owners weekly in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh, with Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs most often washed by owners, and Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes least often. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley noted that people have less time, cars are bigger, children are less willing to earn money this way, and there are now plenty of choices for car washing services.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact since his 2008 arrival at Anfield, stating Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool, having helped Skrtel settle at the club. Skrtel believes Liverpool can overcome the challenge of replacing Gerrard, as the club has potential replacements who will need support. Gerrard is set to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to reach the final on his birthday before moving to LA Galaxy. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return for the Villa match after serving three-match bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved his first ace at Augusta National during the par-3 contest, hitting a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was one of five hole-in-ones that day, leveling a 2002 record, with Camilo Villegas also making two aces but losing the title to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, who became the youngest to wear a green jacket in 1963 and won his sixth in 1986, is also one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms and reports of twisters, including one northwest of Goddard near Wichita, with nighttime tornadoes noted as the most deadly. Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri was also affected, with a possible tornado in Potosi causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees, while unusual dark clouds were seen in Leadington and baseball-sized hail in Farmington. More storms are expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he mistakenly used a gun instead of a taser during an arrest on April 2. A judge granted Bates permission for a family vacation to the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as a display of apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2. Allegations suggest Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff, with claims that supervisors were told to forge his records, though the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these. Bates' lawyers have released training documents to counter these claims, and two deputies involved in Harris's arrest were reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas, where Aldo will make his eighth title defense. Ahead of the fight, McGregor unveiled a new tiger's face tattoo on his stomach, adding to a gorilla tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it, and their relationship is fractious, as shown when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, who argued he was glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. Critics stated that as Prime Minister, he should advocate against binge drinking and set a better example, rather than promoting a culture focused on how quickly and how much one can drink. The incident involved Abbott downing a schooner in about six seconds, cheered by a crowd, and was also criticized for the reactions of media and other government officials, such as Opposition Leader Bill Shorten's quip and Health Minister Sussan Ley's defense of Abbott's fitness. While acknowledging drinking is part of Australian tradition, Dr. Robert highlighted that the climate regarding binge drinking concerns has changed, making such actions problematic.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County, primarily among intravenous drug users of the painkiller Opana. Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program for Scott County, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used syringes, and he is currently reviewing whether to extend it beyond April 25. Despite Pence's general opposition to needle exchanges, the emergency program was deemed a necessary reaction to the outbreak. Legislation to allow needle exchange programs in other Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates has passed the House and is moving to a conference committee, but its future is uncertain due to concerns about promoting drug use and a lack of long-term funding, as federal funding is banned and Pence's order did not include money for the program.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about his favorite football club, which she posted on Twitter. Saskia scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning an 'A' grade, and her boyfriend commented that he would not dump her as a result. The test included various question formats, and while Saskia struggled with some player positions, she scored well on creative answers, even receiving double marks for a comment about Eden Hazard. Her boyfriend provided feedback, including areas for improvement and drawing an angry face for incorrect answers. The incident sparked mixed reactions on Twitter, with some praising the boyfriend as a 'legend' and Saskia as 'proper gf material,' while others felt he went too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked for the DEA for 27 years as an undercover operative after fleeing Colombia. He became a crucial asset, helping with undercover stings worldwide and aiding in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, in exchange for a promise of US citizenship. Now retired due to declining health, Toro faces deportation as the promised citizenship has not materialized, leaving him technically living in the US illegally. He fears for his life if deported to Colombia, stating he would be killed within hours, and is currently in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits, with his temporary visa expired. The DEA refused to help him with his citizenship after he went public, though a former handler and colleague provided him with funds for an operation.

A 14-year-old girl in India is fighting for her life with 70% burns after setting herself on fire, allegedly following a gang-rape by five men from her village, with her family reportedly telling her to keep quiet about the attack. The incident occurred in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, and the accused men have been arrested. This event takes place amidst heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the ban of the documentary "India's Daughter" about the gang rape and murder of student Jyoti Singh, and other incidents of mob violence against alleged rapists, leading to widespread protests for greater protection for women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford, but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, as he deems them not fit enough to play. Van Gaal wants his team to win to secure a higher position in the table, potentially third place, which would almost certainly qualify them for the top four and exceed their pre-season goal. He acknowledges City will be a tough opponent and emphasizes controlling aggression, rather than seeking revenge for a previous loss. Van Gaal is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford and praised the support of the Manchester United fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Barclays Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Supporters from both clubs expressed disgust at the continuing increase in prices, particularly following the Premier League's Â£5.14 billion TV rights deal, with tickets for the sold-out match starting at Â£64. Organized by groups like Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, the protest aimed to raise awareness of the financial struggles fans face, with banners highlighting the disparity between the TV deal and ticket costs, and calls for tangible reductions to prevent losing a generation of fans.

Newborn baby Star Reader was diagnosed with life-threatening biliary atresia shortly after birth, requiring a liver transplant to survive after an initial operation to unblock her bile ducts was unsuccessful. Neither of Star's parents was a suitable match for the transplant, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, who is her mother's twin sister, offered part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, though she will require lifelong anti-rejection medication. Shanell did not hesitate to donate part of her organ to save her niece.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge, competing in pairs. Hazard and Ake teamed up against Remy and Willian in various challenges, including shooting footballs into car boots from close range and into convertible Audis from long range, as well as playing a tennis-like game over an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake secured wins in the first two rounds with scores of 5-3 and 6-0, but Remy and Willian won the final long-range shooting challenge. During the final challenge, Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the Audis with a long-range shot.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her 29-year-old fiance Jason Timmons. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide for their deaths and assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal, despite prosecutors previously saying he told investigators he was trying to kill himself by driving his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph into an oncoming SUV. His attorneys claim he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, effects of a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis, while his wife described him as a "man of ethics" and expressed devastation to the victims' families.

Lacey Spears was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for killing her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt. Her ex-partner and the boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed on Facebook his hope that she would die in prison, noting her lack of emotion at the sentencing. Prosecutors argued Spears intentionally made her son ill for attention, loading his feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt, while her lawyer maintained her innocence, blamed hospital negligence, and plans to appeal. The judge stated Spears suffers from a mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty," with prosecutors highlighting that Spears used her son's 'illnesses' for self-aggrandizement, leading to his "tortured death."

An improved influenza vaccination, arriving a month later than expected on Australian shores, includes protection against influenza A strain H3N2, influenza B strain B/Phuket, and influenza A strain H1N1. This modification was triggered by a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States caused by H3N2 and B/Phuket, as the previous vaccine was not a good match. High-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts, including Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the influenza specialist group, recommend that everyone get the vaccine, which is expected to be a good match for globally circulating strains, and advise booking shots now despite the delay.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are on the defensive due to an unflattering critique in National Geographic magazine, which described the site as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and being a "disappointment," coinciding with the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. This comes amidst looming budget cuts proposed by Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner, which could eliminate the state historic preservation agency managing the tomb and have already led to reduced hours and staff. Supporters and officials counter that the tomb is in "excellent physical condition" after over $2.5 million in recent renovations, including interior upgrades and ongoing waterproofing, and some visitors also disagree with the negative assessment, finding the site impressive.

Nineties style, including chokers and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, is currently popular, but the potential comeback of JNCO wide-leg jeans has caused dismay among those who wore them previously. The passage highlights several retro fashion trends from the nineties and noughties that are considered "worst offenders" and should remain in the past, yet are making a comeback or are still seen today. These include the bucket hat, camouflage print, the tendency to take trends to the maximum (like double denim), Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, coloured sunglasses, corsets worn as outerwear, and harem trousers, all of which are now sported by a new generation of celebrities.

After heavy rain, four rainbows appeared in the New York area, photographed by Amanda Curtis. China is cracking down on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes. RDJ became agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his private life. The #kyliejennerchallenge involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar to emulate Kylie Jenner. 102-year-old Alice Barker revisited her past with filmmakers. A prom-posal referencing bombs led to a student accusing administrators of racism. Ewan McGregor is cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'. Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer. A pregnancy was announced by referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombed his son.

Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3) to reach the semi-finals. This milestone was celebrated with a giant cake, following a similar celebration for Andy Murray's 500th win. Williams's hopes of playing her sister Venus were dashed when Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams will now face Simona Halep in the semi-finals, after Halep beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. This victory also served as revenge for Williams's shock defeat to Lisicki at Wimbledon in 2013.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani advocate for human rights, free speech, and progressive values, was shot dead by two gunmen in Karachi after locking up her cafe, the second floor (t2f). Mahmud, who had previously received death threats, had just hosted a discussion on disappearances in Balochistan, a sensitive topic that authorities had tried to silence. Her mother was also shot but is expected to recover. Mahmud was known for fostering discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship at her cafe, which served as a hub for those seeking secular wisdom and freedom of thought. Her death, for which no motive has been officially named, sparked widespread grief and gratitude for her courageous work.

West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, numbering around 100,000 people across three generations, have been denied fundamental citizenship rights for decades, including the ability to own property, vote in state elections, or work in state government, leading to abject poverty. This denial stems from fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the Muslim-majority state and a pre-independence law. However, there is new hope for these overwhelmingly Hindu refugees as the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has won a share of power in Kashmir and pledged to normalize their status, though activists warn the community is prepared to take drastic action if their hopes are not met.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly made an offer of around Â£4 million for the Japan international. While Chelsea intends to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, Muto is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and develop. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut, believes he has amazing potential, describing him as an intelligent, fast, strong, and confident player. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto and acknowledged that commercial interests, such as the club's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, influence transfer policy, but emphasized that they only acquire good players or prospects.

Australia is commended for abandoning its policy of not selecting overseas players, a decision that makes England appear old-fashioned for maintaining a similar rule. The passage argues that England coach Stuart Lancaster should be allowed to pick his best players regardless of where they play, citing examples like Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson, whose performances have improved while playing abroad. It stresses that selecting the strongest possible squad is essential for England's World Cup success, particularly as the home team, and that the current policy of excluding talented overseas players is misguided and could lead to missed opportunities. Other nations, such as South Africa and Wales, successfully select their overseas players, demonstrating that England's restrictive policy is an unnecessary hindrance.

Open Garden developed the FireChat app, which facilitates chatting without internet or mobile signal by leveraging wireless mesh networks created through features like Apple's MultiPeer Connectivity Framework. Downloaded over five million times, FireChat allows users to send secure, anonymous messages within 'nearby' chatrooms for those in Bluetooth/Wi-Fi range or 'everyone' chatrooms for broader reach, proving useful in situations like on planes or to save data. To strengthen these off-the-grid networks and extend message range beyond the typical 200ft limit, Open Garden also created Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster. Still under development, Greenstone currently works with FireChat at about 20ft, can store up to 1,000 recent messages, has a one-year battery life, and is designed

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle aims to eliminate negativity around the word 'fat' by embracing it as an honest, body-positive description of her own physique, as explained in her TED Talk. She considers 'fat' a self-descriptor, like 'short' or 'wife', insisting it doesn't equate to 'ugly', challenging societal programming that views 'fat' negatively. Bustle highlights rising size discrimination and the common desire for girls to be thinner, but offers hope by noting that increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater tolerance and acceptance. She uses burlesque to positively expose audiences to a 'fat' body, a practice she found empowering after starting in 2012, and suggests finding a 'courage reference' for self-esteem. Her TED Talk, posted on YouTube, has received mostly positive feedback, including letters of thanks and personal stories, reinforcing her belief that body-positivity is gaining ground.

Theo Walcott, often overlooked this season and frequently on the bench, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013, alongside six Arsenal teammates (Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil) and runway model Olga Sherer. This official portrait features attire similar to what Arsenal's first team stars will wear for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott has been a substitute in 17 of 33 Premier League games, recently playing for six minutes against Chelsea, and hopes to make his first start since March 14 when Arsenal faces Hull.

A collection of 417 original props and puppets, created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker from his Cinovation Studio, will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career, such as the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black valued at $40,000, the Grinch costume at $8,000, and the Mikey costume from Men in Black at $30,000. Other notable items include the Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons, various Gremlins puppets, and pieces from films like Batman Forever, Mighty Joe Young, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker.

Seven-year-old British boy Carwyn Scott-Howell died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother while skiing and falling over a 164ft drop in dense woodland. Carwyn, described by his family as a "daring, outgoing and determined" youngster whose "handsome smile lit up any room," was a competent skier who had started at age three and modelled himself on Bear Grylls. The family was on their last run of a ski holiday in Flaine when he pressed on ahead after his sister lost a ski, and he is believed to have left the piste to head towards the resort he spotted through the trees. Police followed footprints and sliding marks in the snow to his body, and his family expressed "utter devastation" and a "vast void in their hearts."

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old, developed anorexia at 13 due to pressures to be a "size zero" and bullying about her weight, leading her to restrict food intake to as little as one piece of fruit or 100 calories a day and hide meals. Her body began to shut down, resulting in her collapse and a week on a heart monitor in intensive care. Following her hospitalization, Laura received support from eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services for her recovery. She now has a better body image and has reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive body image away from "size zero" stereotypes. The passage also defines anorexia nervosa as a serious mental health condition where individuals try to keep their body weight as low as possible, often by restricting food, making themselves vomit, or increasing exercise, commonly affecting women around 16 or 17.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, designed by New Balance, who secured a record-breaking Â£300 million four-year deal to replace Warrior as suppliers. Players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet modeled the new gingham-designed strip, which features all-white branding, a new collar, and a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster. Despite Sterling recently rejecting a Â£100,000-a-week contract and being linked with Arsenal, Liverpool supporters and the club expect him to remain, with fans explicitly telling him to stay. Players also discussed the importance of the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.
The largest single high-definition map of mysterious dark matter

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings, having previously worked with him in the Holland national team during the 2014 World Cup. Despite competition from other major European clubs like Paris Saint-Germain, United appears to be in a strong position, though Depay's value has increased significantly since Tottenham's Â£15 million offer last summer. Depay is enjoying a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games and helping PSV win the Eredivisie title. Described as a pacy winger with strong dribbling and an explosive right foot, he has been compared to Arjen Robben and even deemed better than a young Cristiano Ronaldo by a scout, and he scored two goals for Holland in the 2014 World Cup.

Chelsea secured a commanding 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side, with Tammy Abraham scoring a double and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The match saw individual performances highlighted for both teams; for Chelsea, Abraham's goals, Ruben Sammut's expert coverage, and Charlie Colkett's captain's shift were noted, while for Manchester City, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored an equalizer, and players like Tosin Adarabioyo and Brandon Barker showed potential despite the team's struggles against a vibrant Chelsea attack.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman, though he is not against gay marriage itself. He insists that state legislators, not courts, should decide on allowing gay marriage, as he does not believe it is a constitutional right. Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cared for, despite disagreeing with the decision, out of respect and love for them, comparing it to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but not stopping him from loving someone who is divorced. He has announced his presidential candidacy and has received monetary commitments exceeding $51 million for the primary season.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are cycling around the world with no plans or agenda, aiming to discover different parts of the planet a pedal at a time. After quitting their restaurant jobs, they are doing it as cheaply as possible, living on less than three euros each per day, with food being their main expense at 2.74 euros each daily. They keep costs down by relying on free accommodation, primarily camping (161 nights), but also using hosting websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and accepting kindness from strangers. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, starting in London and traveling through Europe, including France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and then into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia. They carry 130 kg of gear and plan to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, and cycle the length of the American continent, expecting to be on the road for years.

A Texas couple, married in 2012, is suing James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, claiming his company's photo booth printed racial slurs on their wedding snapshots. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, was alerted months after the event by the bride's sister, who delayed telling them to avoid spoiling their special day. Attorney Cathy Hale represents the couple, who decided to press charges under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract after Evans allegedly did not apologize and told the groom to "sue me." Evans denies all allegations, stating there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption and that the couple showed no mental anguish. The couple's attorney states they primarily seek an apology from Evans, with mediation scheduled and a trial set for July if no agreement is reached. The wedding took place at the Beautiful Bell Tower in northwest Houston, Texas.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to action. He experienced symptoms, including a headache, after the France game, leading him to pull out of Harlequins' clash with Saracens, and had previously been knocked out against Italy, causing him to withdraw from the England-Ireland game. Brown is determined to avoid an extended break, like those suffered by Johnny Sexton or George North, who has been advised not to play again this season due to multiple concussions. Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, gained from World Rugby online modules, helped Brown understand the dangers and make the decision to pull out of games, and he now advocates for teammates to do the same if they show symptoms. His recovery will proceed stage by stage.

Smartphone use is suggested as a factor in the decline of sexual frequency among couples, with research indicating a drop in Britons' sex frequency since the internet's emergence. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a Cambridge University statistician, revealed in his book "Sex by Numbers" that a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. He attributes this to the blurring of public and private lives due to constant connectivity, such as checking emails, which reduces quiet time and squeezes out time for partners as lives become busier with eroded boundaries between home, work, and the outside world. Catherine Mercer also notes that with increasing demands on time, sex falls down the list of priorities, and late-evening work emails can prevent focus on partners at bedtime.

Tibetan Mastiffs, large dogs weighing up to 80 kg and traditionally used for herding, have seen a dramatic decline in popularity in China after previously being prized status symbols that commanded prices up to Â£1.2 million. This decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which ended their use as gifts to officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. Additionally, over-breeding for profit led to a deterioration in the breed's quality, creating a glut of unsellable dogs, and rapid urbanization has made people realize they are not suited for city living. Consequently, many Tibetan Mastiffs are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin, often transported in cruel conditions, with some being stolen or offloaded by unscrupulous breeders.

A survey in Paris found that every woman surveyed claimed to have been a victim of sexual harassment on public transport, with half experiencing it before age 18. The poll of 600 women revealed that "every female user of mass transit has been a victim" of "gender harassment or sexual assault," even if some are unaware due to conditioning. Harassment ranges from insults and intimidating behavior to sex attacks or rape, leading six out of ten women to fear attacks on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. This problem limits women's freedom, forcing them to alter their daily lives and effectively "excludes women from the public arena." The findings prompted calls for a campaign to address sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains, emphasizing the need to educate women that such experiences are not normal and to inform aggressors and witnesses about the legal consequences of sexual assault.

Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix, where groups designed prototype products to address common "everyday emergencies" identified from a survey of 2,000 people, with the top emergency being not being able to sleep. Three products were shortlisted from the Direct Line Everyday Fix Design Makeathon, involving groups from Makerversity: "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that attaches to a key to indicate if a door is locked (red) or open (green); and "Nipper," the world's smallest mobile phone charger that uses household batteries. People can vote for their favorite product on Twitter by retweeting, and the winner, chosen by April 46, will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product.

Police Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under a Ministry of Justice investigation for awarding over Â£500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs alongside Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics, including Keith Vaz, have deemed this "inappropriate" and a conflict of interest, despite Ms. Baird's assertion that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The Ministry of Justice requires PCCs to avoid conflicts of interest when providing victim services and has the power to cease funding if a conflict is established. Chief Constable Sim, who is retiring in June, previously faced a bullying investigation led by Ms. Baird, raising concerns about public reluctance to confide in the service.

Three people have been sentenced and two others are awaiting sentencing for the horrific assault of 53-year-old Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos in late March 2014. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, was identified as the ringleader, believing Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and stolen money/weed. Campbell, along with his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, subjected Valecce to a 42-hour ordeal in a Philadelphia basement, during which he was beaten, filmed, and tattooed with offensive images. Valecce suffered multiple broken bones and later escaped to contact police. Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years in state prison, while Ng received 23 months. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but reports lasting psychological damage.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings, having previously worked with Depay in the Holland national team. PSV confirmed contact with United, Paris Saint-Germain, and a third major European club, noting that Depay's value has increased significantly since Tottenham's Â£15 million bid last summer. The 21-year-old winger has had a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games and helping PSV win the Eredivisie title. Depay, who joined PSV at age 12 and has over 100 appearances, is known for his pace, dribbling, and powerful right-foot shot, often playing on the left wing. He has been compared to Arjen Robben and, by one scout, is considered better than Cristiano Ronaldo was at the same age, having also scored two goals for Holland in the 2014 World Cup.

Chelsea secured a commanding 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side, with Tammy Abraham scoring a double and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The passage details individual player performances from both teams, highlighting key moments such as Abraham's fierce drive and volleyed goals, Solanke's killer finish, and Isaac Buckley-Ricketts' measured finish to bring City level. Players like Tosin Adarabioyo and Jake Clarke-Salter were noted for their defensive presence, while others like Kean Bryan and Brandon Barker had mixed performances, with some missing chances or struggling against strong opposition.
